Aaron Hernandez: Aaron Hernandez, the former NFL tight end for the New England Patriots, was known for his athletic prowess on the field, but his life took a dark turn. He was convicted of first-degree murder in 2015 for the killing of Odin Lloyd, a semi-professional football player. Despite his conviction, Hernandez was posthumously found not guilty of a 2012 double murder in Boston after he committed suicide in his prison cell in 2017. Interestingly, Hernandez's brain was donated for research and was found to have chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), a neurodegenerative disease associated with repeated head injuries, which may have impacted his behavior.
Coronavirus: Coronaviruses are named for the crown-like spikes on their surface, which is visible under an electron microscope. The virus that causes COVID-19 can survive on surfaces for varying lengths of time, with plastic and stainless steel being among the most hospitable surfaces for the virus to linger. Research has shown that the virus can be detected in the air of hospital rooms even after surfaces have been disinfected, highlighting the importance of airborne precautions. Despite the challenges, scientists have developed vaccines at an unprecedented speed, with several vaccines receiving emergency use authorization within a year of the virus's identification.
Patrick Mahomes: Patrick Mahomes has a unique talent on the football field; he can throw a football over 80 yards in the air. This incredible arm strength has earned him the nickname "Showtime" among fans and peers. Off the field, Mahomes is an avid gamer and even streams on Twitch in his spare time. His love for video games has led to partnerships with gaming brands and a friendly rivalry with other NFL players in gaming competitions.
1917 (2019 film): "1917" (2019) is notable for its innovative single-take illusion, which was achieved through the use of hidden cuts and digital effects, making the audience feel as if they are experiencing the film in real-time. Director Sam Mendes drew inspiration for the film from stories told to him by his grandfather, who served in World War I. The film's cinematographer, Roger Deakins, won an Oscar for his work, highlighting the technical mastery involved in creating the seamless visual experience. "1917" also won Best Motion Picture at the Golden Globes, further cementing its impact on both the technical and storytelling aspects of cinema.
Conor McGregor: Conor McGregor, the Irish mixed martial artist, holds the record for the fastest victory in UFC title fight history, winning in just 13 seconds against Jose Aldo at UFC 194 in 2015. Known for his flamboyant style both in and out of the ring, McGregor once showed up to a press conference wearing a suit adorned with his own face. He is the first fighter in UFC history to hold titles in two weight classes simultaneously, having won the featherweight and lightweight championships. Off the fighting mat, McGregor launched his own whiskey brand, Proper No. Twelve, named after his hometown of Crumlin, Dublin, where the postal code begins with "Dublin 12."
Sex Education (TV series): "Sex Education" is a British comedy-drama series that premiered on Netflix in 2019. The show is set in the fictional town of Moordale and follows the life of an awkward teenager, Otis Milburn, who starts a sex therapy clinic at his high school with his friend Maeve Wiley. One of the unique aspects of the series is its use of humor to tackle serious topics such as sexual identity, consent, and relationships. The show has been praised for its diverse and inclusive cast, which includes actors from various backgrounds and sexual orientations, making it a relatable and educational watch for many viewers.
Wikipedia: Wikipedia is a multilingual online encyclopedia created and maintained as an open collaboration project by a community of volunteer editors using a wiki-based editing system. It is the largest and most popular general reference work on the internet, with over 6 million articles in English alone. The name "Wikipedia" is a portmanteau of the words "wiki" (a technology for creating collaborative websites) and "encyclopedia." Jimmy Wales and Larry Sanger launched Wikipedia on January 15, 2001, with Sanger proposing the site's name.
Martin Luther King Jr. was a skilled saxophonist and often played the instrument at civil rights gatherings to help ease tensions and create a sense of unity among attendees. His favorite book was Leo Tolstoy's "The Kingdom of God Is Within You," which deeply influenced his nonviolent approach to social change. King was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1964, making him the youngest recipient at the age of 35. Despite numerous threats to his life, he continued to advocate for civil rights until his assassination in 1968.
Delonte West: Delonte West once played a prank on his teammates by dressing up as a pizza delivery person and surprising them with actual pizzas during a team meeting. He was known for his eclectic taste in music, often playing everything from classical to hip-hop in the locker room before games. West has a tattoo of the Cleveland Cavaliers' logo on his neck, showing his deep loyalty to the team. Despite his NBA career, West has faced numerous personal challenges, including mental health issues, which have been widely publicized in the media.
Feminism: Feminism has its roots in the 18th-century Enlightenment period, but the term "feminism" itself wasn't coined until the late 19th century by French activist Hubertine Auclert. The first wave of feminism focused on legal issues, most notably women's suffrage, while the second wave addressed a wider spectrum of issues, including sexuality and family. Today, feminism continues to evolve, with ongoing debates and movements that span across various cultural, racial, and economic intersections.
Donald Cerrone: Donald Cerrone, known as "Cowboy," holds the record for the most wins in UFC history with 23. He is also famous for his love of adventure, often training in unconventional locations like his personal "Boneyard" gym, which is an outdoor setup filled with old cars and scrap metal. Cerrone has a passion for ranching and owns a large property in New Mexico where he raises cattle and horses. Despite his tough fighter persona, he is known for his charitable work, regularly donating to various causes and helping local communities.
Murder of Odin Lloyd: The murder of Odin Lloyd in 2013 gained significant media attention partly because it involved former NFL player Aaron Hernandez, who was a tight end for the New England Patriots at the time. Hernandez was ultimately convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to life in prison without parole. During the trial, it was revealed that Hernandez had texted a friend to "get a gun" just hours before Lloyd's murder. The case also led to the discovery of Hernandez's involvement in two other murders, which further complicated his legal situation.
Anna May Wong: Anna May Wong was the first Chinese-American actress to gain international stardom. She appeared in over 60 films, including the groundbreaking silent film "The Toll of the Sea" (1922), which was the first feature film to use Technicolor. Despite facing significant racial barriers in Hollywood, Wong became a fashion icon, known for her elegant style and sharp wit. In 1960, she became the first Asian-American actress to host an episode of the television series "The Hollywood Palace."
Parasite (2019 film): "Parasite" (2019), directed by Bong Joon-ho, is the first non-English language film to win the Academy Award for Best Picture. The film cleverly uses a mix of comedy, drama, and thriller elements to explore class conflict and societal inequality. Bong Joon-ho's acceptance speech at the Oscars, where he said, "Once you overcome the one-inch tall barrier of subtitles, you will be introduced to so many more amazing films," has become iconic in the film community. The movie's success sparked a renewed interest in international cinema, leading to a broader recognition of global film talent.
Bad Boys for Life: "Bad Boys for Life" is the third installment in the Bad Boys film series, starring Will Smith and Martin Lawrence, who reprise their roles as detectives Mike Lowrey and Marcus Burnett. The film was directed by Adil El Arbi and Bilall Fallah, making them the first non-American directors in the franchise. Notably, the movie's script was written by Chris Bremner, who initially submitted it as part of a screenwriting competition, and it was later developed into the film. The film's success led to discussions about a potential fourth installment, keeping the franchise alive and continuing the adventures of the iconic duo.
UFC 246: UFC 246, held on January 18, 2020, marked the return of Conor McGregor after a 15-month hiatus from the octagon. McGregor faced Donald "Cowboy" Cerrone in a welterweight bout, which was expected to be a high-octane clash. Surprisingly, the fight ended in just 40 seconds, with McGregor securing a victory via TKO, landing a series of shoulder strikes and punches. This event set a record for the fastest finish in a welterweight main event in UFC history.
Deaths in 2020: In 2020, the global pandemic caused by COVID-19 led to an unprecedented increase in mortality rates worldwide, with over 1.8 million confirmed deaths by the end of the year. This surge in deaths also resulted in a significant shift in how funerals and memorial services were conducted, with many countries imposing restrictions on gatherings to prevent the spread of the virus. Additionally, 2020 saw a notable increase in the use of digital platforms for memorializing the deceased, as virtual services and online tributes became more common. The year 2020 also marked the first time in history that the World Health Organization declared a pandemic in the first quarter of the year, highlighting the severity and rapid spread of the virus.
Sustainable energy: Sustainable energy sources like wind and solar power are not only environmentally friendly but also increasingly cost-effective, with solar photovoltaic systems seeing a dramatic 89% drop in price since 2010. This shift has made renewable energy more competitive with traditional fossil fuels, driving significant investments and installations worldwide. Moreover, the energy generated by wind turbines can be quite entertaining; in Denmark, a wind farm even hosts an annual music festival where the turbines themselves are used to power the event, showcasing the versatility and fun applications of sustainable energy.
List of Super Bowl champions: The Super Bowl champion with the most consecutive wins is the Pittsburgh Steelers and the New England Patriots, each with six titles. The largest margin of victory in a Super Bowl was set by the Dallas Cowboys in Super Bowl XII, winning 27-10 against the Denver Broncos. The smallest margin of victory was a single point, achieved by the New York Giants in Super Bowl XXV, defeating the Buffalo Bills 20-19. The only team to win a Super Bowl in their home stadium was the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in Super Bowl LV, held at Raymond James Stadium in Tampa, Florida.
Tanhaji: Tanhaji Malusare was a 17th-century Maratha warrior, known for his bravery and leadership under Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj. He famously led a covert night attack to recapture the strategic fort of Sinhagad, now known as Kondhana. Tanhaji is celebrated in Marathi folklore as a symbol of valor and loyalty. The story of his life inspired the 2020 Bollywood film "Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior," which highlighted his contributions to the Maratha Empire.
Terry Jones: Terry Jones, best known as a member of the Monty Python comedy group, was also an accomplished medieval historian. He wrote several books on the subject, including "Who Murdered Chaucer?" and "Chaucer's Knight: The Portrait of a Medieval Mercenary." Surprisingly, Jones directed some of Monty Python's most famous films, such as "Monty Python and the Holy Grail," despite having no prior experience in directing. His unique blend of humor and historical insight made him a distinctive figure in both comedy and academia.
Meghan, Duchess of Sussex: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, originally known as Meghan Markle, is a former actress who starred in the popular TV show "Suits" as Rachel Zane. She is an avid calligrapher and even took on freelance calligraphy jobs before her acting career took off. Meghan is a global ambassador for World Vision and traveled to Rwanda for the Clean Water Campaign. She has a degree in Communications from Northwestern University.
Elizabeth II: Elizabeth II is known for her love of Corgis, a breed of dog she has owned since she was seven years old. She has owned more than 30 Corgis throughout her life, often breeding them from her own dogs. The Queen is also reported to have a keen sense of humor, once joking that she needed to lose weight so she could fit into a horse-drawn carriage. Her personal wealth is estimated to be around £350 million, which includes her extensive art collection and investments.
Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex: Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, is an avid supporter of the Invictus Games, an international adaptive multi-sport event for wounded, injured, or sick military personnel and veterans. He is also a qualified Apache helicopter pilot, having served in the British Army for ten years, including two tours in Afghanistan. Prince Harry co-founded the charity Sentebale to help children and young people affected by HIV/AIDS in Lesotho and Botswana. He holds the rank of Captain in the Royal Navy, Major in the Army, and Squadron Leader in the Royal Air Force Reserves.
Andy Reid: Andy Reid, the head coach of the Kansas City Chiefs, is known for his love of cheeseburgers. During a game against the Denver Broncos in 2013, he famously ordered a cheeseburger from the stadium kitchen during halftime, which he ate while watching the replay on the monitor. His son Britt Reid, who is also a coach, once joked that his dad's diet consists of "cheeseburgers, cheeseburgers, and more cheeseburgers." Reid's penchant for fast food even inspired a special menu item at a Kansas City restaurant, the "Big Red" cheeseburger, which includes two beef patties, bacon, and a fried egg.
Media: Media often influences public opinion through subtle framing of news stories. For example, a study found that when newspapers used more positive adjectives to describe a political candidate, readers were more likely to view that candidate favorably. This phenomenon, known as "framing," can significantly sway voter perceptions and behaviors without them even realizing it. Interestingly, the impact of such framing can be stronger than the actual content of the messages themselves.
Crisis on Infinite Earths (Arrowverse): "Crisis on Infinite Earths" is a landmark crossover event in the Arrowverse, spanning five episodes across multiple TV shows including "Arrow," "The Flash," "Supergirl," "Batwoman," and "Legends of Tomorrow." The event brought together characters from various Earths, including a surprise appearance by Tom Welling as Clark Kent from "Smallville." One of the most emotional moments was when The Flash (Barry Allen) met his comic book counterpart, Jay Garrick, who gave him the iconic "Flash signal" helmet. The crossover also featured a touching tribute to the late actor Brandon Routh, who played both The Atom and a Kingdom Come-inspired Superman, a role he first portrayed in the 2006 film "Superman Returns."
Jimmy Garoppolo: Jimmy Garoppolo holds the NFL record for the highest completion percentage in a single game, achieving a remarkable 98.1% against the Jacksonville Jaguars in 2019. Despite being a second-round pick, he signed the largest contract in NFL history at the time, worth $137.5 million with the San Francisco 49ers in 2018. Garoppolo is known for his love of country music and has been spotted attending concerts and even meeting with artists like Blake Shelton. Before his NFL career, he played college football at Eastern Illinois, where he won the Walter Payton Award, given to the most outstanding player in the NCAA Division I FCS.
Joker (2019 film): "Joker" (2019) is notable for being the first live-action superhero film to win the prestigious Golden Lion at the Venice Film Festival. Joaquin Phoenix, who portrayed the Joker, lost 52 pounds for the role, a transformation that contributed to his intense and haunting performance. The film's score, composed by Hildur Guðnadóttir, won an Academy Award, making her the first woman to win Best Original Score for a comic book film. The movie sparked significant debate over its potential to inspire real-world violence, leading to increased security measures at screenings.
MBC 2 (Middle East and North Africa): MBC 2 is a popular 24-hour movie channel in the Middle East and North Africa, known for showcasing a diverse range of films from Hollywood and beyond. It was the first-ever free-to-air movie channel in the region, launching in 2003. The channel frequently hosts themed movie nights, such as "Action Thursdays" or "Family Sundays," to cater to different viewer preferences. MBC 2 also occasionally airs exclusive premieres and special interviews with Hollywood stars, making it a go-to destination for film enthusiasts across the MENA region.
2019\u201320 outbreak of novel coronavir: The 2019-20 outbreak of the novel coronavirus, later named COVID-19, began in Wuhan, China, in December 2019. This virus, SARS-CoV-2, is believed to have originated from a seafood market in Wuhan that also sold live animals. The outbreak quickly escalated into a global pandemic, marking the first time the World Health Organization (WHO) declared a public health emergency of international concern in the 21st century. A unique aspect of this pandemic was the rapid development and deployment of vaccines, with several receiving emergency use authorization within a year of the virus's identification, a record-breaking pace in vaccine development.
Kansas City Chiefs: The Kansas City Chiefs, originally known as the Dallas Texans, were founded in 1960 as a charter member of the American Football League (AFL). In 1962, the team won the AFL Championship in a thrilling double-overtime game against the Houston Oilers, which is still considered one of the greatest games in professional football history. The Chiefs moved to Kansas City in 1963 and switched to the NFL when the AFL and NFL merged in 1970. They hold the distinction of being the second AFL team to defeat an NFL team in an AFL-NFL World Championship, now known as the Super Bowl, when they won Super Bowl IV in 1970.
Royal Rumble (2020): In the 2020 Royal Rumble, Roman Reigns eliminated 13 competitors, the most of any wrestler in that event, showcasing his dominance. Edge made a surprising return after a nine-year absence due to injury, entering at number 21 and lasting over 30 minutes. The match featured a record 13 former Royal Rumble winners, adding a layer of prestige and nostalgia. Charlotte Flair became the third woman to win a Royal Rumble match, following in the footsteps of Becky Lynch and Asuka, marking a historic moment for women in WWE.
Luka Magnotta: Luka Magnotta, a Canadian murderer and body mutilator, gained notoriety for his gruesome crimes, including the killing and dismemberment of Chinese international student Jun Lin in 2012. Magnotta filmed parts of his crime and posted the videos online, which led to his international manhunt and eventual capture in Berlin. His case became a subject of global media attention and was dubbed "Canada's most horrific crime" by some news outlets. Magnotta was convicted and sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole for 25 years.
Jennifer Aniston: Jennifer Aniston was born in Sherman Oaks, California, but she moved to New York City as a teenager to pursue a career in acting. She initially worked as a telemarketer, bike messenger, and waitress before landing her breakthrough role in "Friends." Aniston is not only an actress but also a businesswoman; she co-founded the production company Echo Films in 2008. Despite her fame, she remains close to her mother, Nancy Dow, despite their public feud, and has a passion for yoga, which she practices regularly to maintain her health and well-being.
The Witcher (TV series): The Witcher, based on the book series by Andrzej Sapkowski, features Henry Cavill as Geralt of Rivia, who underwent intense physical training and swordsmanship lessons to accurately portray the character. The show's original score, composed by Sonya Belousova and Giona Ostinelli, includes instruments like the nyckelharpa, which is traditional to Nordic folk music and enhances the series' medieval fantasy atmosphere. An interesting behind-the-scenes detail is that the character of Yennefer, played by Anya Chalotra, had her makeup designed to subtly change over the seasons to reflect her evolving magical abilities and emotional states. The Witcher also holds the record for the most in-demand digital original series premiere in the history of Netflix, surpassing even "The Mandalorian" from Disney+.
Music to Be Murdered By: "Music to Be Murdered By" is the eleventh studio album by American rapper Eminem, released without prior announcement in January 2020. The album's title and cover art are a homage to the 1956 Alfred Hitchcock album "Music to Be Killed By." Eminem worked with various producers and artists, including Dr. Dre, Skylar Grey, and Juice WRLD, who contributed before his untimely death. The album sparked controversy and debuted at number one on the Billboard 200 chart, making it Eminem's tenth consecutive album to achieve this feat.
Raheem Mostert: Raheem Mostert, an NFL running back, began his career as a special teams standout, playing for seven teams over five seasons before finding a stable role with the San Francisco 49ers. Despite his early struggles with injuries and roster instability, Mostert showcased his speed and agility by setting a 49ers franchise record with 220 rushing yards in the 2019 NFC Championship game against the Green Bay Packers. His journey from undrafted free agent to playoff hero is a testament to his perseverance and talent. Mostert's performance in that game was the second-highest rushing total in a single playoff game in NFL history, underscoring his impact on the field.
Brad Pitt: Brad Pitt once worked as a limousine driver, chauffeuring celebrities like Martin Sheen and Elizabeth Taylor. He co-founded the production company Plan B Entertainment, which produced the Oscar-winning film "12 Years a Slave." Pitt is known for his philanthropic efforts, particularly his involvement in rebuilding New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina. Despite his Hollywood success, he once admitted to having a fear of flying, which he overcame by taking flying lessons and obtaining his pilot's license.
Subhas Chandra Bose: Subhas Chandra Bose, an Indian nationalist leader, famously used the alias "Netaji," which means "Respected Leader" in Hindi. During World War II, Bose led the Indian National Army (INA) against British forces, with the slogan "Delhi Chalo" ("March to Delhi"). He is believed to have collaborated with Nazi Germany and Imperial Japan to gain support for India's independence struggle. Despite his mysterious disappearance in 1945, Bose remains a revered figure in India, inspiring numerous films, books, and monuments.
Aaron Rodgers: Aaron Rodgers has a passion for golf and has participated in several celebrity golf tournaments, often competing against other sports stars. He is known for his love of Jeopardy!, having been a contestant on the show and later hosting the game show for a special event. Rodgers is also an avid fan of the Star Wars franchise, often referencing it in his interviews and social media posts. His competitive nature extends off the field, as he once won a triathlon in his hometown of Chico, California.
Once Upon a Time in Hollywood: "Once Upon a Time in Hollywood" features a scene where Leonardo DiCaprio's character, Rick Dalton, accidentally sets fire to the set during a dramatic scene, a moment that was unscripted and genuinely surprised the cast and crew. Margot Robbie, who plays Sharon Tate, spent much of her screen time in the film without dialogue, emphasizing visual storytelling and her character's presence. The film's vintage cars were so authentic that Quentin Tarantino had to remind the cast not to use modern car features like Bluetooth or GPS, to maintain the period feel. Lastly, the film's ending, which diverges from historical events, was kept a closely guarded secret, with Tarantino only revealing it to the actors just before they shot the scenes.
Dolittle (film): "Dolittle," a 2020 fantasy adventure film, stars Robert Downey Jr. as the titular character, Dr. John Dolittle. The film features an ensemble voice cast of animals, including Emma Thompson, Rami Malek, and John Cena, among others. It is based on the children's book series "The Voyages of Doctor Dolittle" by Hugh Lofting. Notably, the film was originally titled "The Voyage of Doctor Dolittle" but was shortened for its release.
Severe acute respiratory syndrome: Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) is a viral respiratory illness caused by the SARS coronavirus (SARS-CoV). The outbreak of SARS in 2002-2003 was notable for its rapid spread from China to more than two dozen countries, primarily through international air travel. During the peak of the outbreak, health care workers accounted for about 20% of reported cases, highlighting the virus's ability to spread in health care settings. The World Health Organization declared the global SARS outbreak as contained on July 5, 2003, with a total of 8,098 known cases and 774 deaths, making it a significant but ultimately controlled global health crisis.
Charles, Prince of Wales: Charles, Prince of Wales, is known for his love of traditional architecture and has been a vocal advocate for the preservation of historic buildings. He established the Prince's Foundation for Building Community, which promotes sustainable and traditional architecture. Interestingly, Charles is also a certified helicopter pilot and has used his piloting skills to support various royal engagements and humanitarian efforts. Additionally, he holds the record for being the longest-serving Prince of Wales, having held the title since 1958.
Star Trek: Picard: "Star Trek: Picard" features Sir Patrick Stewart reprising his iconic role as Jean-Luc Picard, a character he first played in "Star Trek: The Next Generation." The series is set 20 years after the events of "Star Trek: Nemesis" and explores Picard's life after retiring from Starfleet. It introduces new characters alongside appearances from familiar faces like Seven of Nine and Riker. The show delves into themes of memory, legacy, and the impact of past decisions on future generations.
Brooklyn: Brooklyn is home to the world's largest collection of art deco architecture, with many of its buildings designed in the 1920s and 1930s. The borough's Coney Island is famous for its annual Mermaid Parade, which is the largest art parade in the United States and celebrates the seaside heritage. Brooklyn Botanic Garden features a Japanese cherry blossom festival every spring that attracts thousands of visitors. Lastly, Brooklyn was an independent city until 1898 when it officially became a part of New York City.
Princess Margaret, Countess of Snowdon: Princess Margaret, Countess of Snowdon, was the younger sister of Queen Elizabeth II and the first British royal to undergo a lung operation, which she had in 1965 to remove a part of her lung due to cancer. She was known for her glamorous lifestyle and was the first royal to be photographed smoking a cigarette, which she did in 1956. Despite her royal duties, Margaret was also a talented painter and had several of her watercolors privately exhibited. Her personal life was often in the spotlight, particularly her controversial love affair with Group Captain Peter Townsend, which made headlines worldwide in the 1950s.
Emma Mackey: Emma Mackey, known for her role as Maeve Wiley in the Netflix series "Sex Education," was actually born in Le Mans, France, rather than the UK. Before her acting career took off, she studied at the University of Leeds, where she earned a degree in Media and Communication. Mackey has also appeared in the 2021 film "Eiffel," where she played the role of Adrienne Bourgery, a character inspired by the real-life muse of Gustave Eiffel. Despite her rising fame, she remains private about her personal life, often keeping details away from the public eye.
Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh: Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was an avid carriage driver and competed in numerous international competitions well into his eighties. He was known for his sense of humor, once famously telling a British student in China, "If you stay here much longer, you'll all be slitty-eyed." Despite his royal status, Philip attended Gordonstoun, a Scottish boarding school known for its rigorous and Spartan-like education, which he described as "bloody awful" but later sent his own children there. He was also a patron, president, or member of over 780 organizations and launched the Duke of Edinburgh's Award scheme in 1956, which has since encouraged millions of young people worldwide to participate in various developmental activities.
Joaquin Phoenix: Joaquin Phoenix initially started his career as a child actor alongside his siblings in a group called "The Children of God," performing street shows and attending various talent competitions. He is known for his commitment to his roles, having once lost 52 pounds for his role as Johnny Cash in "Walk the Line," a transformation that took him through a physically and mentally challenging journey. Despite his serious demeanor on screen, Phoenix is an avid animal rights activist and has been a vegan since the age of three. He infamously accepted his Best Actor award at the 2020 Oscars by using the platform to advocate for the environment and animal rights, urging viewers to reconsider their consumption of animal products.
The Outsider (miniseries): "The Outsider" miniseries, based on Stephen King's novel, features a haunting score by composer Nathan Barr, known for his work in "True Blood" and "The Americans." The series stars Ben Mendelsohn as Detective Ralph Anderson, who investigates a disturbing crime that defies conventional explanation. Despite its dark themes, the show incorporates elements of supernatural and crime genres, blending them into a unique narrative. The Outsider premiered on HBO in January 2020, receiving critical acclaim for its gripping storytelling and atmospheric tension.
BBC World Service: BBC World Service, the international broadcasting arm of the British Broadcasting Corporation, originally began as a means to broadcast news and programming in the English language during World War II. It has since expanded to offer programming in over 40 languages, reaching an estimated 304 million listeners weekly. The service is funded by the UK government but operates independently of political influence, adhering to the BBC's editorial guidelines. Notably, BBC World Service was instrumental in the spread of information during the Cold War, providing a counterpoint to state-controlled media in many Eastern Bloc countries.
Eminem: Eminem, born Marshall Mathers, holds the record for the most words rapped in a hit single; his song "Rap God" contains a staggering 1,560 words in just over six minutes. Despite his tough public persona, Eminem has a soft spot for animals; he owns several dogs and often shares photos of them on social media. He has won 15 Grammy Awards, making him one of the most awarded artists in the history of the ceremony. Eminem's daughter, Hailie Jade, was the inspiration behind many of his songs, including the hit "Hailie's Song," and she graduated from Michigan State University with a degree in psychology.
Novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV):
The novel coronavirus, known as SARS-CoV-2, which causes the disease COVID-19, has a crown-like appearance under a microscope due to the spike proteins protruding from its surface, giving it its name "corona," which means crown in Latin.

This virus is highly contagious and can spread through respiratory droplets when an infected person talks, coughs, or sneezes, leading to a global pandemic that has affected millions of people worldwide.

One of the most effective ways to prevent the spread of COVID-19 is through the use of masks, social distancing, and frequent handwashing, measures that have become commonplace in many societies during the pandemic.

Scientists around the world collaborated at an unprecedented speed to develop vaccines against the novel coronavirus, with several vaccines receiving emergency use authorization within a year of the virus's identification, a record-breaking achievement in the field of medicine.
Kepler's Supernova: Kepler's Supernova, discovered by Johannes Kepler in 1604, is one of the last supernovae observed in the Milky Way galaxy. This supernova was brighter than Jupiter and visible during the day for several weeks, providing a spectacular show for skywatchers of the time. The remnant of Kepler's Supernova, known as SNR 012.0+04, is still expanding and is estimated to be around 13,000 light-years away from Earth. Astronomers study this remnant to understand the physics of supernovae and the processes that occur during a massive star's final moments.
Khabib Nurmagomedov: Khabib Nurmagomedov, the undefeated former UFC lightweight champion, holds the record for the most takedowns in UFC history with a staggering 216 takedowns in his career. His nickname, "The Eagle," is derived from his Avar heritage, symbolizing strength and vision, mirroring his fighting style. Khabib's father, Abdulmanap Nurmagomedov, was a decorated wrestler and served as his primary coach, instilling discipline and a rigorous training regimen. Despite his fierce reputation in the octagon, Khabib is known for his deep commitment to Islam and his family, often expressing gratitude to his faith and loved ones after his fights.
Tim Tebow: Tim Tebow, a former NFL quarterback, is also known for his successful college football career at the University of Florida, where he won the Heisman Trophy in 2007. He gained additional fame for his habit of inscribing Bible verses on his eye black during games, a practice that eventually led to a change in NCAA rules. Off the field, Tebow has ventured into professional baseball, signing with the New York Mets organization in 2016, despite not having played baseball since high school. He is also actively involved in philanthropy, founding the Tim Tebow Foundation, which aims to bring faith, hope, and love to those needing a brighter day in their darkest hour.
Martin Luther King Jr. Day: Martin Luther King Jr. Day is celebrated on the third Monday of January, which means it always falls close to King's actual birthday on January 15. The day was officially recognized as a federal holiday in 1986, but it took until 2000 for all 50 states to acknowledge it as such. Many communities use the day not only to honor King's legacy but also as a day of service, encouraging volunteerism and community involvement. The holiday is one of only four federal holidays dedicated to a single individual, the others being Presidents' Day (honoring George Washington), Columbus Day, and Veterans Day.
San Francisco 49ers: The San Francisco 49ers, named after the gold prospectors of the 1849 Gold Rush, were the first major league professional sports franchise to be based in San Francisco. They have won five Super Bowl championships, tied for the second-most in NFL history. The team's iconic stadium, Levi's Stadium, is known for its cutting-edge technology, including Wi-Fi access points that outnumber the seats. Notably, the 49ers were the first team in NFL history to have a female assistant coach, Katie Sowers, on their staff.
Adam Schiff: Adam Schiff, a prominent American politician, is known for his love of literature and has a personal library that includes over 2,000 books. He often references classic literature in his speeches and interviews, drawing parallels between literary themes and contemporary political issues. Schiff is also an advocate for the arts, having supported various cultural programs and initiatives throughout his career. Interestingly, he once participated in a dramatic reading of Shakespeare's "Julius Caesar" where he played the role of Brutus.
You (TV series): "You" is a psychological thriller TV series based on the novel by Caroline Kepnes. The show revolves around a bookstore manager named Joe Goldberg who becomes dangerously obsessed with a customer named Beck. In the second season, the setting shifts from New York to Los Angeles, introducing a new obsession for Joe with a woman named Love. The series is known for its deep dive into the dark psychology of stalking and obsession, often blurring the lines between love and madness.
Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker: In "Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker," the character Babu Frik, a tiny droidsmith, is voiced by the same actor who played Yoda in the prequel trilogy, Frank Oz. Babu Frik's ability to reprogram and repair droids is crucial to the film's plot, showcasing a unique connection between the old and new generations of Star Wars characters. The film also features the return of Emperor Palpatine, whose resurrection is orchestrated through a series of complex Sith rituals and technologies, hinting at the enduring power and mystery of the Sith. Additionally, the movie concludes with a touching moment where Leia Organa uses the Force to communicate with her son, Kylo Ren, one last time, mirroring the iconic Force ghost scenes from the original trilogy.
Terminator: Dark Fate: "Terminator: Dark Fate" is a 2019 science fiction action film that serves as a direct sequel to "Terminator 2: Judgment Day," ignoring the events of the subsequent sequels. The film introduces a new Terminator model, the Rev-9, which can split into two separate entities, making it a formidable opponent. Linda Hamilton reprises her iconic role as Sarah Connor, marking her first appearance in the franchise since "Terminator 2" and her on-screen reunion with Arnold Schwarzenegger. The film was directed by Tim Miller, known for his work on "Deadpool," and was produced by James Cameron, the director of the first two "Terminator" films.
Wuhan: Wuhan, known as the "Chicago of China," is the birthplace of the Yangtze River civilization, with a history dating back over 3,500 years. The city is famous for its Wuhan Hot Dry Noodles, a local snack that has been elevated to a national dish and is enjoyed by millions every day. Wuhan is also home to the Wuhan University, one of China's most prestigious institutions, which boasts one of the most beautiful campuses in the world, particularly renowned for its cherry blossoms. Lastly, Wuhan is the transportation hub of central China, with the world's longest continuous bridge-tunnel complex, the Wuhan Yangtze River Bridge, connecting the city's three towns.
XXXX: XXXX is a versatile material known for its strength and durability. It can be found in everything from aerospace components to everyday household items. Surprisingly, XXXX can also be used to create musical instruments, offering a unique sound due to its resonant properties. Its adaptability makes it a favorite among engineers and designers alike.
Jimmy Hoffa: Jimmy Hoffa, the notorious former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, mysteriously disappeared on July 30, 1975, and has never been found. Despite numerous theories and investigations, the exact circumstances of his disappearance remain one of the greatest unsolved mysteries in American history. Hoffa was known for his aggressive tactics in labor negotiations and his alleged ties to organized crime, which led to his conviction and imprisonment from 1967 to 1971. His disappearance has inspired countless books, movies, and conspiracy theories, making it a staple topic in American folklore.
Super Bowl LIV: Super Bowl LIV, held in 2020, was the first Super Bowl to feature two brothers coaching against each other, with San Francisco 49ers head coach Kyle Shanahan facing off against his brother, Kansas City Chiefs offensive coordinator Eric Bieniemy. The halftime show, headlined by Jennifer Lopez and Shakira, was the first to feature two Latin American artists as the main performers. The Chiefs' victory marked their first Super Bowl win in 50 years, ending the longest active championship drought in the NFL. The game was played at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Florida, which became the first stadium to host the Super Bowl for a record-tying sixth time.
Annabella Sciorra: Annabella Sciorra, an accomplished American actress, is best known for her role in the 1992 film "The Hand That Rocks the Cradle," which was a box office success. She later gained critical acclaim for her performance in Spike Lee's 1999 film "Jungle Fever." Sciorra made a significant impact on television as well, starring in the popular series "The Sopranos" as Gloria Trillo, a character whose volatile relationship with Tony Soprano became a highlight of the show. Beyond her acting career, Sciorra is also a trained dancer, having studied ballet at the Herbert Berghof Studio in New York City.
Ala Vaikunthapurramuloo: "Ala Vaikunthapurramuloo," a Telugu-language film, features a song titled "Butta Bomma" which became a massive hit, garnering over 500 million views on YouTube. The film's soundtrack, composed by S. Thaman, was highly acclaimed and contributed significantly to its commercial success. Starring Allu Arjun and Pooja Hegde, the movie is known for its stylish action sequences and vibrant cinematography. "Ala Vaikunthapurramuloo" also marked a milestone as one of the highest-grossing Telugu films of 2020, solidifying Allu Arjun's position as a leading star in the Telugu film industry.
Blue Monday (date): Blue Monday, typically referred to as the third Monday in January, is often dubbed the most depressing day of the year. This designation was popularized by a British psychologist, Cliff Arnall, who formulated a calculation involving weather conditions, debt levels, time since Christmas, and failed New Year's resolutions. Despite its scientific-sounding origin, the concept has been widely criticized as a marketing gimmick rather than a genuine psychological phenomenon. The idea was initially used to promote travel deals, suggesting that people might feel particularly down and in need of a vacation on this day.
2020 Australian Open: In the 2020 Australian Open, Sofia Kenin, a 21-year-old American, clinched her first Grand Slam title by defeating Garbiñe Muguruza in the final. This tournament also marked the longest match in terms of time, with Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal's third-round encounter lasting five hours and 15 minutes. The event was notable for its extreme weather conditions, including a heatwave that led to the tournament's extreme heat policy being invoked. Additionally, the tournament was the first Grand Slam to implement a final-set tiebreak, which was used when the score reached 6-6 in the final set of all matches.
The Irishman: "The Irishman," directed by Martin Scorsese, is a crime epic based on the book "I Heard You Paint Houses" by Charles Brandt. The film famously used de-aging technology to portray its lead actors, Robert De Niro, Al Pacino, and Joe Pesci, across several decades. Despite its lengthy runtime of nearly three and a half hours, it received widespread acclaim for its storytelling and performances. The Irishman marked the first time Scorsese, De Niro, and Pacino collaborated on a film together, a long-awaited partnership in cinematic history.
Betty White: Betty White holds the record for the longest television career of any entertainer, spanning over 80 years. She began her career in 1939, long before TV became a common household item. White was an animal rights activist and worked closely with the Los Angeles Zoo and various animal organizations throughout her life. Despite her comedic roles, she served as a co-host of the Tournament of Roses Parade in 1986 and 1987, showcasing her versatility in the entertainment industry.
Donald Trump: Donald Trump once appeared as a guest on WWE's Monday Night Raw, where he "body-slammed" and shaved Vince McMahon's head in a staged event that drew significant media attention. He holds the record for the most tweets sent by a U.S. President in a single day, with 123 messages on January 6, 2021. Trump is known for his love of golf; he owns and operates several golf courses worldwide, including in Scotland and Ireland. Despite his often controversial public persona, Trump is a fan of the musical "Les Misérables," and has seen it multiple times, even inviting the cast to perform at the White House.
Super Bowl: The Super Bowl is the only day in the U.S. where it's legal to buy a pizza, a bucket of chicken, and a six-pack of beer on the same trip to the grocery store. The event's halftime show is one of the most-watched musical performances in the world, with audiences often exceeding those of the actual game. The Vince Lombardi Trophy, awarded to the winning team, is handmade by Tiffany & Co. artisans in Parsippany, New Jersey, and each trophy is unique, with the engraving of the winning team's information done by hand. Super Bowl commercials are a major event in themselves, with companies spending millions on 30-second spots to capture the attention of the massive audience, often featuring celebrity appearances and elaborate productions.
Diana, Princess of Wales: Diana, Princess of Wales, was known for her compassionate nature and humanitarian work. She famously walked through an active minefield in Angola in 1997 to raise awareness about landmines. Diana was also a talented pianist and often played for her friends and family in private. Her iconic "revenge dress" was worn to a Vanity Fair party hours after her separation from Prince Charles was announced, turning heads and making fashion history.
United States: The United States is home to the world's first national park, Yellowstone, which was established in 1872 and features dramatic canyons, alpine rivers, lush forests, and a plethora of wildlife, along with the famous geysers and hot springs. The country also boasts the longest cave system in the world, Mammoth Cave National Park in Kentucky, which has more than 400 miles of explored passageways. Additionally, the U.S. is the birthplace of the world's first skyscraper, the Home Insurance Building in Chicago, which was completed in 1885 and stood 10 stories high. Lastly, the United States Navy Blue Angels, the country's premier flight demonstration squadron, was formed in 1946 and continues to perform aerial stunts and flyovers at air shows across the nation.
Asa Butterfield: Asa Butterfield, known for his roles in films like "Hugo" and "Ender's Game," started his acting career at the age of seven. Interestingly, he was discovered in a Sunday acting class where he was the only student who showed up that day. Butterfield is also an avid gamer and has expressed his love for video games in various interviews, even mentioning that he enjoys playing "World of Warcraft" in his free time. Despite his busy acting schedule, he managed to complete his high school education through online courses, maintaining a balance between his professional and academic life.
Stephen Ward: Stephen Ward, a British osteopath, gained notoriety in the early 1960s as the central figure in the Profumo Affair, a political scandal that rocked the British government. Ward was known for his social connections, bridging the worlds of aristocracy, politics, and the entertainment industry. His trial and subsequent death from an overdose of barbiturates while in police custody sparked significant public outcry and debate about the fairness of the British legal system. The scandal ultimately led to the downfall of several prominent political figures and marked a turning point in British society, highlighting the moral and social changes of the era.
Billie Eilish: Billie Eilish is known for her unique sense of style, often wearing oversized clothing to feel comfortable and to avoid being sexualized by the media. She co-wrote and recorded her hit song "Bad Guy" in her childhood bedroom with her brother Finneas. Billie is a vegan and is very vocal about her support for animal rights and environmental issues. Despite her young age, she has won multiple Grammy Awards, including the prestigious "Record of the Year" and "Album of the Year."
92nd Academy Awards: The 92nd Academy Awards, held in 2020, was notable for being the first time in 30 years that a foreign-language film won Best Picture, with Bong Joon-ho's "Parasite" achieving this historic feat. Bong Joon-ho also became the first Korean director to win Best Director, and his film swept four major awards: Best Picture, Best Director, Best International Feature Film, and Best Original Screenplay. The ceremony was hostless for the second consecutive year, a trend that began in 2019. Despite the absence of a host, the show featured a memorable performance by Janelle Monáe that opened with a tribute to the movie musical genre.
Little Women (2019 film): In the 2019 adaptation of "Little Women," director Greta Gerwig chose to structure the narrative in a non-linear fashion, alternating between past and present to highlight the characters' growth and the impact of their decisions. Saoirse Ronan, who plays Jo March, performed her own stunts in the film, including a scene where she runs through a snowy field. The film features an original score by Alexandre Desplat, which includes a waltz composed specifically for the character of Jo March. Gerwig's version of "Little Women" received six Academy Award nominations, including Best Picture, making it the first film based on a Louisa May Alcott novel to achieve this distinction.
Pat Mahomes: Patrick Mahomes, the quarterback for the Kansas City Chiefs, holds the record for the most passing yards in a single game, throwing for 505 yards in 2018. He is also the youngest quarterback to throw for 5,000 yards in a season, achieving this feat at the age of 24. Off the field, Mahomes is an avid gamer and has participated in various gaming tournaments, showcasing his competitive spirit beyond football. Additionally, he co-owns a professional esports organization called "Kansas City Royals," which further highlights his passion for gaming.
Apple Network Server: Apple Network Server (ANS) was a line of server computers designed and manufactured by Apple Computer in the late 1990s. It was a significant departure from Apple's traditional consumer-focused products, as it targeted the enterprise market. The ANS ran on the AIX operating system, which was IBM's version of Unix, rather than Apple's own macOS. Despite its innovative design and powerful hardware, the Apple Network Server failed to gain significant market traction and was discontinued after only two years, marking one of Apple's few ventures into the server market.
Gillian Anderson: Gillian Anderson, best known for her role as Dana Scully in "The X-Files," is an avid reader and has a personal library that contains over 3,000 books. She is also a passionate advocate for various social causes, including raising awareness about neurodegenerative diseases. In addition to her acting career, Anderson has authored a series of children's books titled "The Great Jungle Mystery Series." Interestingly, she once appeared in a stage production of "The Vagina Monologues" in London, where she performed in the nude for one of the monologues.
Tanaji Malusare: Tanaji Malusare was a legendary Maratha warrior, best known for his role in the Battle of Sinhagad in 1670. He was the military leader of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj's fort raiders, known as the Maratha Swarajya. Tanaji is celebrated for his bravery and loyalty; it is said that he climbed the steep cliffs of the fort using a rope made of cow's tail hair, a technique known as "Gajar Ka Pull." After his death during the battle, Shivaji is quoted to have said, "We gained the fort, but lost the lion," referring to Tanaji's exceptional valor.
Periodic table: The periodic table is organized by atomic number, which is the number of protons in an atom's nucleus. This organization reveals fascinating patterns, such as the periodic repetition of chemical and physical properties among elements. Dmitri Mendeleev, often credited as the inventor of the modern periodic table, famously left gaps in his original table, correctly predicting the existence and properties of elements that had not yet been discovered. One of these predicted elements, gallium, was discovered shortly after, confirming Mendeleev's foresight and the accuracy of his table's arrangement.
Edward VIII: Edward VIII, who reigned as King of the United Kingdom for less than a year in 1936, is best known for his decision to abdicate the throne to marry Wallis Simpson, an American socialite who had been divorced twice. This unprecedented move made him the only British monarch to voluntarily relinquish the crown for the sake of love. Prior to his reign, Edward served in the British military and was known for his flamboyant lifestyle and numerous romantic affairs. After his abdication, he was given the title of Duke of Windsor, and he and Wallis lived primarily in France, where they continued to attract media attention and controversy.
White House Farm murders: The White House Farm murders, which occurred in 1985 in Essex, England, initially led police to suspect the daughter of the family, Sheila Caffell, who was found dead alongside her parents and twin six-year-old sons. However, after a controversial and flawed investigation, it was revealed that the true perpetrator was Sheila's brother, Jeremy Bamber, who staged the crime scene to frame his sister. Bamber was later convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment, where he remains one of the most notorious British serial killers. The case has been the subject of several documentaries and a recent TV series, highlighting the investigative errors and the chilling details of the crime.
Kyle Shanahan: Kyle Shanahan, the head coach of the San Francisco 49ers, is the son of former NFL coach Mike Shanahan. He is known for his innovative offensive play-calling and was the offensive coordinator for the Atlanta Falcons when they reached Super Bowl LI. Interestingly, Shanahan is a big fan of rock music and often incorporates song references into his play calls. Despite his team's loss in Super Bowl LI, Shanahan earned respect for his strategic acumen and resilience in leading the 49ers to the Super Bowl again in the 2019 season.
Jojo Rabbit: "Jojo Rabbit" is a satirical comedy-drama directed by Taika Waititi, who also plays the titular character, an imaginary friend in the form of Adolf Hitler. The film, set during World War II, follows a young German boy whose naive patriotism is challenged when he discovers his mother is hiding a Jewish girl in their home. Waititi based the character of Jojo on his own childhood memories of being a ten-year-old in New Zealand during the Gulf War, where he imagined having a friend like Hitler who shared his views. The movie won the People's Choice Award at the Toronto International Film Festival and was nominated for six Academy Awards, including Best Picture.
Nikola Tesla: Nikola Tesla had an unusual fear of pearls, which he believed could cause him harm; he once avoided a dinner party because the hostess was wearing a pearl necklace. He claimed to have received visions of future inventions, which he then built, including the AC motor. Tesla was an avid pigeon lover, and he often spoke of a particular white pigeon he considered his closest friend. Despite his eccentricities, Tesla held over 300 patents worldwide and revolutionized the field of electrical engineering.
Chronic traumatic encephalopathy: Chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) is a progressive brain condition believed to be caused by repeated head injuries, often seen in athletes like football players and boxers. The symptoms of CTE, which include memory loss, confusion, depression, and erratic behavior, can only be diagnosed posthumously through brain tissue analysis. Despite its prevalence in contact sports, CTE was only officially recognized by the medical community in 2002, after a study by Dr. Bennet Omalu on the brain of former NFL player Mike Webster. Research into CTE is ongoing, with scientists exploring potential treatments and preventive measures to protect athletes and others at risk from its debilitating effects.
Elon Musk: Elon Musk once appeared as himself on an episode of "The Big Bang Theory," where he worked at the restaurant where Penny, one of the main characters, was a waitress. He has a peculiar eating habit; he often eats a single meal in the middle of the night, which he refers to as his "first dinner." Musk is known for his spontaneous and sometimes erratic tweeting, which has landed him in legal troubles and public controversies multiple times. Despite his busy schedule, Musk claims to sleep only about six hours a night, believing that it's enough to function effectively.
Sharon Tate: Sharon Tate was an actress and model who gained fame in the 1960s, starring in films like "Valley of the Dolls" and "The Fearless Vampire Killers." She was married to director Roman Polanski and was eight months pregnant with their first child at the time of her tragic death. Tate was a close friend of the fashion designer Valentino, who often dressed her for events. Despite her untimely death at the age of 26, her legacy as a style icon and talented actress continues to influence pop culture.
Laurence Fox: Laurence Fox, known for his role as DS James Hathaway in the British TV series "Lewis," is also a talented musician. He released his debut album, "Holding Patterns," in 2016, showcasing his skills as a singer-songwriter. Fox is part of a famous acting dynasty; his father is actor James Fox, and his cousins include Emilia Fox and Freddie Fox. Beyond acting and music, he ventured into politics, founding the political party Reclaim in 2020, aiming to challenge what he perceives as the dominance of identity politics in the UK.
2019\u201320 Wuhan coronavirus outbreak: The 2019–20 Wuhan coronavirus outbreak, later named COVID-19, was first identified in the city of Wuhan, China, in December 2019. The virus, known as SARS-CoV-2, quickly spread globally, leading the World Health Organization to declare a Public Health Emergency of International Concern in January 2020. One of the most unusual aspects of the pandemic was the widespread adoption of face masks, which became a ubiquitous symbol of the crisis. Additionally, the outbreak spurred significant scientific advancements, including the rapid development of multiple vaccines within a year, a feat previously thought impossible.
Judy Garland: Judy Garland was originally cast as Peter Pan in a planned film adaptation, but the project was eventually scrapped. She was known for her powerful rendition of "Over the Rainbow" from "The Wizard of Oz," which was almost cut from the film due to concerns it slowed the pace. Garland's daughter, Liza Minnelli, followed in her footsteps to become a renowned entertainer in her own right. Despite her immense success, Garland struggled with personal and professional challenges throughout her life, including battles with addiction and mental health issues.
A Fall from Grace: "A Fall from Grace" is a 2020 Netflix thriller film directed by Tyler Perry. The movie, which stars Crystal Fox and Phylicia Rashad, revolves around a woman who believes she has found true love, only to be charged with the murder of her husband. Despite its release on the streaming platform, the film received overwhelmingly negative reviews from critics, who criticized its plot and execution. Interestingly, Tyler Perry not only directed the film but also wrote, produced, and acted in it, showcasing his multi-faceted involvement in the project.
Jeff Bezos: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, once worked at McDonald's during his teenage years, where he flipped burgers and operated the cash register. He is an avid space enthusiast and founded Blue Origin, a private aerospace manufacturer and sub-orbital spaceflight services company. Bezos is known for his unique laugh, which has been described as a cross between a hyena's chuckle and a full-bellied guffaw. Despite his wealth, Bezos drives a modest Honda Accord, which he reportedly used to drive to work even after Amazon became a billion-dollar company.
123Movies: 123Movies, once a popular online streaming platform, was known for hosting a vast library of movies and TV shows without requiring users to sign up or pay. Despite its popularity, the site faced numerous legal challenges and shutdowns due to copyright infringement issues. Its operators often changed domain names and rebranded to evade authorities, showcasing a cat-and-mouse game with copyright enforcers. Today, several similar sites have emerged under different names, continuing the trend of providing free access to copyrighted content, albeit with ongoing legal risks for both the operators and users.
Ken Miles: Ken Miles, a renowned British race car driver, famously participated in the 1966 24 Hours of Le Mans where he was instructed to slow down and allow another car to cross the finish line first, creating a controversial photo finish. Despite his impressive driving skills, Miles never won the prestigious Le Mans race as a solo driver; his best finish was second overall in 1959. His tragic death in a crash during a test drive for the Ford J-Car in 1966 cut short a promising career that had already seen him set numerous speed records and win key races in the United States. Miles' life and career were later portrayed in the 2019 film "Ford v Ferrari," where he was played by Christian Bale.
Adam Driver: Adam Driver, known for his intense performances in films like "Star Wars" and "Marriage Story," started his career in the Marines before transitioning to acting. He co-founded a nonprofit organization called Arts in the Armed Forces, which brings high-quality arts programming to active-duty service members, veterans, and their families. Driver is also an accomplished singer and once performed with the band Low in a surprise concert at the 2018 Sundance Film Festival. Despite his serious on-screen persona, he has a reputation for humor and spontaneity, often surprising fans and interviewers with his wit and charm.
Dwayne Johnson: Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson is a descendant of a long line of professional wrestlers; his grandfather, Peter Maivia, and his father, Rocky Johnson, were both prominent figures in the wrestling world. Before his acting career took off, Johnson played college football at the University of Miami, where he was a part of the 1991 National Championship-winning team. He holds the record for the most Instagram followers among any male actor, showcasing his immense popularity in social media. Off-screen, Johnson is known for his charitable work, including founding the Dwayne Johnson Rock Foundation, which helps children with life-threatening illnesses.
George VI: George VI, who ascended to the British throne in 1936 following his brother Edward VIII's abdication, was initially seen as a reluctant king. He overcame a significant stammer, famously depicted in the film "The King's Speech," with the help of speech therapist Lionel Logue. During his reign, he led the United Kingdom through World War II, earning him the nickname "The People's King." George VI was the first British monarch to make a royal Christmas broadcast on television in 1957.
World War I: World War I introduced the first widespread use of chemical weapons, with chlorine and mustard gas causing horrific casualties and long-term health effects. The war also saw the debut of the tank, a revolutionary armored vehicle that reshaped battlefield tactics. The Christmas Truce of 1914, where opposing soldiers along the Western Front exchanged gifts and played soccer, remains a poignant symbol of human kindness amidst conflict. Additionally, the war led to the creation of the poppy as a symbol of remembrance for the fallen, inspired by the poem "In Flanders Fields" by John McCrae.
The Outsider (King novel): "The Oresund Space Collective is a group of musicians from Denmark and Sweden who play space rock and psychedelic music. They are known for their improvisational style and have released over 30 albums since their formation in 2005. The collective often performs live without prior rehearsals, allowing their music to evolve spontaneously during performances. Their collaborative and free-flowing approach to music has earned them a dedicated following among fans of experimental and progressive rock."
Patrick Stewart: Patrick Stewart, best known as Captain Jean-Luc Picard from "Star Trek: The Next Generation," once performed in a production of "Macbeth" where the set caught on fire during a performance. Despite the chaos, Stewart and the cast continued the show, delivering their lines in the smoky theater, and the audience remained unaware of the danger until the end of the act. Stewart is also an advocate for domestic violence prevention and has been a patron of Refuge, a British charity working to help women and children affected by domestic violence, since 1979. In addition to his acting career, Stewart holds a black belt in Taekwondo, which he earned at the age of 68.
Erling Braut H\u00e5land: Erling Braut Håland, the Norwegian footballer, holds the record for being the youngest player to score 20 goals in a single season in the UEFA Champions League, achieving this feat at the age of 19. He is known for his distinctive "zenit" celebration, where he points to the sky after scoring a goal, a tribute to his late younger brother who was named after the Russian football club Zenit Saint Petersburg. Håland's father, Alf-Inge Håland, was also a professional footballer, playing for clubs like Leeds United, Manchester City, and Nottingham Forest. Despite his young age, Håland has already been compared to football legends like Cristiano Ronaldo and Zlatan Ibrahimović for his goal-scoring prowess and physical presence on the field.
2020 Australian Open \u2013 Men's Single: In the 2020 Australian Open Men's Singles final, Novak Djokovic faced Dominic Thiem in a thrilling match that lasted over four hours. Djokovic won his eighth Australian Open title, defeating Thiem in five sets, 6-4, 4-6, 2-6, 6-3, 6-4. This victory extended Djokovic's record as the player with the most Australian Open titles in the Open Era. The final was notable for its dramatic shifts in momentum, with Thiem pushing Djokovic to the brink before the Serbian star rallied to secure the win.
Ted Kaczynski: Ted Kaczynski, also known as the Unabomber, was a mathematical prodigy who entered Harvard University at the age of 16. He later became a professor of mathematics at the University of California, Berkeley, but resigned in 1969, citing a dislike for the modern world and its technological advancements. Kaczynski lived as a recluse in a small cabin without electricity or running water in the Montana wilderness for over two decades. His manifesto, "Industrial Society and Its Future," which outlined his anti-technology beliefs, was published by The Washington Post and The New York Times after he threatened to kill more people if it wasn't.
Mac Miller: Mac Miller's real name is Malcolm James McCormick. He taught himself to play multiple instruments, including the piano, guitar, bass, and drums, by the age of 6. Miller's debut album, "Blue Slide Park," became the first independently distributed debut album to top the US Billboard 200 since 1995. He was known for his collaborative efforts, working with artists across various genres, including hip-hop, pop, and even electronic music.
Monty Python: Monty Python, a British comedy group, was formed in 1969 and consisted of six members: Graham Chapman, John Cleese, Terry Gilliam, Eric Idle, Terry Jones, and Michael Palin. Their iconic TV series, "Monty Python's Flying Circus," was known for its absurd humor and breaking of the fourth wall, often surprising viewers with unexpected transitions and non-sequitur sketches. One of their most famous sketches, "The Dead Parrot," features John Cleese trying to return a clearly deceased parrot to a pet shop, arguing that it is merely "resting" or "pining for the fjords." The group's influence extends beyond television, as they also created the comedy film "Monty Python and the Holy Grail," which features coconuts being used as horse hooves and a killer rabbit as one of the film's most memorable scenes.
Jorge Masvidal: Jorge Masvidal, a renowned mixed martial artist, holds the record for the fastest knockout in UFC history, achieving it in just five seconds against Ben Askren at UFC 239. Outside the octagon, Masvidal is known for his street fighting background, having gained early recognition through his participation in backyard brawls organized by the legendary Kimbo Slice. He is also an avid fisherman and often shares his passion for the sport on social media, showcasing his catches and fishing adventures. Despite his tough-guy persona, Masvidal is a devoted father and frequently posts about his family life, highlighting his softer side away from the fighting world.
The Mandalorian: The Mandalorian, a live-action Star Wars series, features a bounty hunter named Din Djarin who operates under a strict code known as the "Mandalorian creed." One of the most iconic elements of the show is the character Baby Yoda, officially named "The Child," who has become a cultural phenomenon and a beloved figure among fans. The series introduced a new type of stormtrooper called the "Dark Trooper," which is a high-tech, heavily armored variant designed for elite combat missions. The Mandalorian is notable for its use of practical effects and puppetry, which harkens back to the original Star Wars trilogy's approach to visual effects, providing a more tactile and immersive experience for viewers.
Republic Day (India): Republic Day in India, celebrated on January 26th each year, marks the adoption of the Indian Constitution in 1950. The highlight of the celebrations is the grand Republic Day parade in New Delhi, showcasing India's military prowess and cultural diversity. One unique feature is the "Tableaux" from various states, each depicting a theme or aspect of the state's heritage and development. Additionally, the parade includes a display of the Indian Army's daredevil motorcycle stunts, known as the "Maitree Motorcycle Display Team," which is a thrilling spectacle for spectators.
Henry Cavill: Henry Cavill, known for his role as Superman in the DC Extended Universe, is an avid gamer and has participated in charity livestreams for organizations like SpecialEffect. He once revealed that he was the second choice for the role of James Bond in "Casino Royale," losing out to Daniel Craig. Cavill is also a skilled horse rider, a skill he showcased in the TV series "The Tudors." Interestingly, he was once considered for the role of Cedric Diggory in the "Harry Potter" series but was deemed too old for the part.
Isabel dos Santos: Isabel dos Santos, often referred to as Africa's richest woman, made her fortune through investments in various sectors including telecommunications, banking, and retail. She controversially rose to prominence as the daughter of Angola's former president, José Eduardo dos Santos. Her business empire has been scrutinized by international media and financial watchdogs, with allegations of corruption and nepotism. Despite the controversies, she remains a prominent figure in African business and has been a vocal advocate for women's empowerment in the corporate world.
YouTube: YouTube was created by three former PayPal employees—Chad Hurley, Steve Chen, and Jawed Karim—in February 2005. The first video ever uploaded to YouTube, titled "Me at the zoo," was posted by co-founder Jawed Karim and features him talking about elephants at the San Diego Zoo. YouTube originally started as a video dating site called "Tune In Hook Up," but quickly pivoted to a broader audience after realizing the potential of user-generated content. As of 2021, YouTube has over 2 billion monthly active users, making it one of the most visited websites in the world.
Chinese New Year: Chinese New Year is celebrated for 15 days, culminating in the Lantern Festival, where colorful lanterns are displayed and families enjoy sweet rice balls called "tangyuan." The festival marks the end of the celebrations, symbolizing reunion and prosperity. Firecrackers and fireworks are traditionally set off to ward off evil spirits and bring good luck for the new year. Each day of the celebration has specific customs and activities, reflecting various aspects of Chinese culture and folklore.
Connor Swindells: Connor Swindells, a British actor known for his roles in "Sex Education" and "VS.", is also an accomplished chess player. Before pursuing acting full-time, he competed in regional chess tournaments in England. Swindells often incorporates his strategic thinking from chess into his acting performances, enhancing his ability to portray complex characters. Interestingly, he once played a chess match against a fellow actor during a break on set, turning downtime into a competitive yet friendly challenge.
Aimee Lou Wood: Aimee Lou Wood is an English actress best known for her role as Aimee Gibbs in the Netflix series "Sex Education." She initially auditioned for the role of Maeve Wiley, but the producers saw her potential in a different character. Wood's performance has been praised for its authenticity and humor, making Aimee Gibbs a beloved character among fans. Off-screen, she is an advocate for mental health awareness and often shares her experiences and insights on social media.
Rocky Johnson: Rocky Johnson, born as Wayde Douglas Bowles, was a professional wrestler who made a significant impact in the wrestling world. He was the first black wrestler to win the World Tag Team Championship in the World Wrestling Federation (WWF) alongside his partner Tony Atlas. His son, Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson, followed in his footsteps and became one of the most famous wrestlers and actors in the world. Rocky Johnson was inducted into the WWE Hall of Fame in 2008, cementing his legacy in the sport.
Bombshell (2019 film): "Bombshell" (2019) is a biographical drama film that explores the sexual harassment scandal at Fox News. Charlize Theron underwent extensive prosthetic makeup to portray Megyn Kelly, closely mimicking her appearance and mannerisms. The film features a cameo by real-life Fox News host Sean Hannity, played by himself, making a brief on-screen appearance. "Bombshell" received critical acclaim, particularly for its performances, and earned several awards and nominations, including an Academy Award for Charlize Theron's portrayal of Megyn Kelly.
Chhapaak: "Chhapaak" is a 2020 Indian Hindi-language drama film directed by Meghna Gulzar. The film is based on the real-life story of Laxmi Agarwal, an acid attack survivor. Deepika Padukone, who plays the lead role, also co-produced the film, marking her first venture as a producer. The film's title, "Chhapaak," translates to "splash," symbolizing the traumatic event that changes the protagonist's life.
You (season 2): In "You" Season 2, the protagonist Joe Goldberg moves from New York to Los Angeles to escape his past. The show's setting shift brings a new aesthetic, with the use of vibrant colors and palm trees to contrast the darker, grittier New York backdrop of Season 1. Joe's new obsession, Love Quinn, is not just a romantic interest but also a fellow killer, which adds a complex layer to their relationship. The season also introduces the "Glass Man" theory, where Joe's perception of people as either "good" or "bad" is challenged, reflecting his own moral ambiguity.
Bigg Boss (Hindi season 13): Bigg Boss Hindi Season 13, which aired from September 2019 to February 2020, holds the record for being the longest-running season, extending its duration by an additional 33 days due to its immense popularity. The season was hosted by Salman Khan, who has been the face of the show since its fourth season. One of the most controversial yet engaging contestants of this season was Sidharth Shukla, who eventually won the title, gaining massive fan following and popularity. The season also introduced a unique twist where contestants could earn immunity from nominations by winning weekly tasks, adding an extra layer of strategy and competition among the housemates.
Ncuti Gatwa: Ncuti Gatwa, known for his role as Eric Effiong in the Netflix series "Sex Education," was born in Rwanda but moved to Scotland at a young age. He initially aspired to be a doctor but switched to acting after discovering his passion for the stage. Gatwa's breakthrough role in "Sex Education" earned him a BAFTA Scotland nomination for Best Actor in a Television Drama. Outside of acting, he is an advocate for LGBTQ+ rights and mental health awareness.
Halsey (singer): Halsey, whose real name is Ashley Frangipane, has a unique way of creating her stage name by re-arranging the name of the Halsey Street subway stop in Brooklyn where she used to live. She has a condition called endometriosis, which inspired her to become an advocate for women's health and has influenced her music. Halsey is of Italian, Hungarian, and African-American descent, making her a diverse cultural blend. She once performed at a Taylor Swift concert as an opening act, which significantly boosted her career.
Michael Bloomberg: Michael Bloomberg, born as Michael Rubens Bloomberg, is an American businessman, politician, and author who served as the 108th Mayor of New York City for three consecutive terms starting from 2002. He is the founder and majority owner of Bloomberg L.P., a financial software, data, and media company that he started in 1981 after being fired from his job at Salomon Brothers. Despite his immense wealth, Bloomberg is known for his frugal habits; he famously drives his own car and has been spotted filling up his own gas tank. In 2020, Bloomberg briefly entered the Democratic presidential primaries, spending over $1 billion of his own money on his campaign, though he ultimately suspended his campaign and endorsed Joe Biden.
Sex:
Sexual arousal can be influenced by a variety of factors, including visual, auditory, and tactile stimuli, as well as personal fantasies and memories.

The human body experiences a surge in the hormone oxytocin during sexual activity, which can enhance feelings of bonding and attachment.

In many species, including humans, the scent of certain pheromones can play a role in sexual attraction and mate selection.

Sexual education and open communication about sexual health can significantly reduce the risk of sexually transmitted infections and improve overall sexual well-being.
Liv Tyler: Liv Tyler, born Liv Rundgren, initially believed that her biological father was musician Todd Rundgren, but later discovered through a paternity test that Aerosmith's frontman, Steven Tyler, was her real father. She made her film debut at the age of 14 in the film "Silent Fall."
