Liv is known for her role as Arwen Undómiel in the "Lord of the Rings" trilogy, where she famously rode a horse through a river in one continuous shot. Off-screen, she is a dedicated philanthropist, actively supporting organizations like the Make-A-Wish Foundation and the GO Campaign.
Greta Thunberg: Greta Thunberg, the renowned climate activist, began her journey by skipping school every Friday to protest outside the Swedish Parliament, a movement she dubbed "Fridays for Future." This simple act of protest quickly escalated into a global movement, inspiring millions of students worldwide to join in and demand action on climate change. Despite her young age, Thunberg has addressed the United Nations, met with world leaders, and was even nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize in 2019. Her influence has been so profound that Time magazine named her one of the 100 most influential people in the world in 2019 and Person of the Year in 2019.
2020 European Men's Handball Championshi: The 2020 European Men's Handball Championship, held in Austria, Norway, and Sweden, was the first time the tournament was hosted by three countries simultaneously. The event saw a dramatic final where Spain defeated Croatia 22-20, securing their second European title. Notably, the championship introduced a new format with 24 teams competing, up from the previous 16, increasing the number of matches and overall competitiveness. This expansion led to a more diverse representation of European handball nations, showcasing a wider array of playing styles and talent.
Eli Manning: Eli Manning, a two-time Super Bowl MVP, famously refused to play for the San Diego Chargers when he was drafted, leading to a trade that sent him to the New York Giants. He holds the record for the most fourth-quarter touchdown passes in NFL history, a testament to his clutch performances. Off the field, Manning is known for his sense of humor, having participated in numerous comedic skits during his time with the Giants, including a memorable appearance on Saturday Night Live. Despite his competitive nature, he once played a charity basketball game against a team of disabled children and scored only one point, ensuring the children's team won the game.
India: India is home to the largest film industry in the world by the number of films produced, known as Bollywood, which is based in Mumbai and primarily produces movies in Hindi. The country also boasts the second-largest road network globally, spanning over 5.5 million kilometers, which is a vital lifeline for its vast population. India's traditional greeting, "Namaste," is not just a polite salutation but is also believed to carry spiritual significance, symbolizing the belief that the divine lives within each person. Lastly, the Indian cuisine is incredibly diverse, with each region offering unique flavors and dishes, reflecting its rich cultural and historical tapestry.
James Earl Ray: James Earl Ray, the man who assassinated Martin Luther King Jr., initially fled the United States and spent time in various countries before being captured in London. Ray was a small-time criminal with a history of petty thefts and forgery before he shot King. Despite his guilty plea, Ray later recanted and claimed he was framed, attempting to gain a trial to prove his innocence. His life in prison was marked by numerous escape attempts and he died in 1998 at the age of 70.
Richard Jewell: Richard Jewell was initially hailed as a hero for discovering a bomb at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics and helping to evacuate the area, potentially saving lives. However, within days, he became the focus of a massive FBI investigation, wrongly suspected of being the bomber himself. The intense media scrutiny turned his life into a nightmare, with his face plastered across newspapers and television worldwide. Eventually, after 88 days, Jewell was cleared, and Eric Rudolph was identified and convicted as the actual Olympic Park bomber.
List of Bollywood films of 2020: In 2020, Bollywood saw a significant shift in its film release patterns due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with many major films opting for direct digital releases instead of traditional theatrical premieres. One notable example was "Gulabo Sitabo," starring Amitabh Bachchan and Ayushmann Khurrana, which became one of the first major Bollywood films to premiere on an OTT platform, Amazon Prime Video. This move marked a new era for Bollywood, as filmmakers and studios explored new ways to reach audiences during the lockdown. Despite the challenges, 2020 also saw the release of several critically acclaimed films like "Shakuntala Devi" and "Chhichhore," showcasing the industry's resilience and adaptability.
Robert Downey Jr. started his acting career at the age of five, appearing in the film "Pound" directed by his father, Robert Downey Sr. He is a talented musician, playing the synthesizer in the band "The Futurists" and even contributed vocals and guitar to some of his movie soundtracks. Despite his struggles with substance abuse, Downey Jr. holds the record for the most MTV Movie Awards won for a single role, thanks to his portrayal of Tony Stark in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Off-screen, he is known for his wit and humor, often entertaining fans and interviewers with his quick-thinking and sharp comebacks.
Angelina Jolie: Angelina Jolie is a passionate humanitarian who has been a Goodwill Ambassador for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) since 2001. She has visited over 30 countries to advocate for refugees and has even been awarded the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award for her extensive philanthropic work. Off-screen, Jolie is an accomplished pilot, having earned her private pilot's license and flown humanitarian missions to transport medical supplies. Additionally, she has a tattoo of a Tennessee Williams quote, "A prayer for the wild at heart, kept in cages," inked on her left arm, reflecting her adventurous spirit.
Cristiano Ronaldo: Cristiano Ronaldo holds the record for the most goals scored in the UEFA Champions League, with over 130 goals to his name. He is also the first player to win the league's top scorer award for six different seasons. Off the field, Ronaldo is known for his philanthropic work, including donating millions to various charities and even funding the construction of a pediatric hospital in his native Portugal. Additionally, he has a strong passion for fashion and owns his own line of clothing and fragrances.
The Witcher: The Witcher series, created by Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski, features a protagonist named Geralt of Rivia who possesses supernatural abilities due to being subjected to a series of mutations. These mutations enhance his physical abilities and grant him heightened senses, making him an exceptional monster hunter. The series gained immense popularity after it was adapted into a video game by CD Projekt Red, which introduced a complex narrative and moral choices that influenced the game's world and characters. The success of the video game further propelled the franchise into a Netflix original series, starring Henry Cavill as Geralt, which has been praised for its dark fantasy elements and intricate storytelling.
Impeachment of Bill Clinton: The impeachment of Bill Clinton in 1998 was sparked by his affair with White House intern Monica Lewinsky and his subsequent denial under oath. During the trial, Clinton's approval ratings actually rose, surprising many political analysts. The House of Representatives impeached Clinton on two charges: perjury and obstruction of justice, but he was acquitted by the Senate, allowing him to complete his second term. A notable moment during the impeachment proceedings was when Clinton famously declared, "I did not have sexual relations with that woman, Miss Lewinsky," which later proved to be false.
Heath Ledger: Heath Ledger was an avid chess enthusiast and often played the game with friends and family. Before his rise to fame, he worked as a clown at birthday parties to support himself. Ledger was known for his meticulous approach to character development, famously locking himself in a hotel room for a month to prepare for his role as the Joker in "The Dark Knight." Despite his young age, he left an indelible mark on the film industry, earning a posthumous Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor for his portrayal of the Joker.
Knives Out (film): "Knives Out," directed by Rian Johnson, features a star-studded cast including Daniel Craig, Chris Evans, and Ana de Armas. The film's title is a nod to the Agatha Christie mystery novel "A Pocket Full of Rye," where the phrase "knives out" refers to a situation where everyone is suspicious of each other. Johnson wrote the role of Benoit Blanc specifically for Daniel Craig, inspired by Hercule Poirot and Columbo. The movie was a critical and commercial success, earning an Academy Award nomination for Best Original Screenplay and spawning a sequel, "Glass Onion: A Knives Out Mystery."
Mike Vrabel: Mike Vrabel, currently the head coach of the Tennessee Titans, is a former NFL linebacker known for his versatility on the field. During his playing career, Vrabel was part of three Super Bowl-winning teams with the New England Patriots. One of his most memorable moments came in Super Bowl XXXVIII when he caught a touchdown pass, despite being a defensive player. Off the field, Vrabel is known for his charitable work, including his involvement with the Vrabel Fund, which supports various community initiatives in Ohio and Tennessee.
Frank Sheeran: Frank Sheeran, also known as "The Irishman," was a reputed labor union official and hitman associated with the Bufalino crime family. He claimed to have killed over 25 people during his criminal career, including his close friend, Teamsters president Jimmy Hoffa. Sheeran's life story was the subject of the 2019 Netflix film "The Irishman," directed by Martin Scorsese and starring Robert De Niro as Sheeran. Despite his criminal activities, Sheeran maintained a close relationship with his family, particularly his daughters, throughout his life.
2020 Democratic Party presidential prima: The 2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries featured a historically diverse field of candidates, including six senators, two governors, a mayor, a billionaire, and a former Vice President. Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren led the progressive wing of the party, advocating for significant policy changes like Medicare for All and the Green New Deal. Despite initial frontrunner status, Joe Biden's campaign struggled in the early primaries but staged a dramatic comeback after securing the endorsement of several key Democratic figures. The primaries also marked the first time that all states and territories held their contests by mail or other remote means due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
World War II: During World War II, a pig named "William of Orange" lived through the bombing of Rotterdam in the Netherlands in 1940, surviving unscathed and even gaining weight. The pig's survival became a symbol of hope and resilience among the Dutch people. In a bizarre twist, William of Orange was later killed and eaten by a group of soldiers, who believed that consuming him would bring them good luck. Despite this, the story of William's survival remained a popular tale of wartime perseverance.
Anne, Princess Royal: Anne, Princess Royal, is known for her equestrian prowess; she competed in the 1976 Montreal Olympics, making her the first member of the British Royal Family to participate in an Olympic event. She has a strong connection to wildlife conservation, serving as president of the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (RSPCA) since 1981. Anne is also the only daughter of Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, and she holds the record for the longest-serving Princess Royal in British history. Despite her royal duties, she is known for her straightforward and sometimes blunt manner, which has endeared her to some and surprised others.
Holly Holm: Holly Holm, a former professional boxer and mixed martial artist, holds an impressive record of 33 wins in professional boxing, with 9 of those victories coming by way of knockout. She made history by defeating Ronda Rousey at UFC 193 in 2015, becoming the first person to beat Rousey and the first woman to win a UFC fight by head kick knockout. Holm's diverse fighting background includes titles in boxing, kickboxing, and MMA, making her one of the few athletes to achieve championship status in multiple combat sports. Off the ring, Holm is also a certified personal trainer and has been involved in fitness and wellness coaching.
Coca-Cola: Coca-Cola was originally formulated in 1886 by pharmacist John Stith Pemberton in Atlanta, Georgia, as a medicinal tonic. The iconic Coca-Cola logo, designed by Frank Mason Robinson, uses a signature Spencerian script, a popular penmanship style of the time. Interestingly, the original recipe contained cocaine, derived from the coca leaf, which was removed in 1903. Today, Coca-Cola is one of the most recognized brands worldwide, sold in over 200 countries.
Crash Landing on You: "Crash Landing on You" is a South Korean television series that gained international popularity, particularly in regions where Korean dramas are not commonly broadcast. The show features a unique plot where a South Korean heiress, played by Son Ye-jin, accidentally lands in North Korea after a paragliding accident. The series is notable for its meticulous attention to detail in portraying both South and North Korean cultures, including the use of actual North Korean defectors as consultants. Its success led to a significant increase in tourism to Switzerland, where several key scenes were filmed, as fans sought to recreate the romantic moments from the show.
Doomsday Clock: The Doomsday Clock, managed by the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, is a symbolic clock face that represents the likelihood of a global catastrophe. It was originally set at seven minutes to midnight in 1947, reflecting the heightened tensions of the Cold War. The clock has been adjusted 24 times since its inception, with the closest approach to midnight being two minutes away in 1953, following the United States and Soviet Union's nuclear tests. As of 2023, the clock remains at 100 seconds to midnight, the closest it has ever been to symbolic midnight, indicating the Bulletin's most urgent warning about global threats.
Awkwafina: Awkwafina, whose real name is Nora Lum, started her career as a rapper, releasing her first album "Yellow Ranger" in 2014. She gained widespread attention with her song "My Vag," which led to her being featured on "The Howard Stern Show" and "The Today Show." Beyond music, Awkwafina has made a successful transition to acting, with notable roles in films like "Crazy Rich Asians" and "Ocean's 8." Her unique blend of humor and talent has earned her both critical acclaim and a growing fan base.
Robert De Niro: Robert De Niro is known for his method acting, famously gaining 60 pounds for his role as Jake LaMotta in "Raging Bull." He co-founded the Tribeca Film Festival in 2002 to revitalize Lower Manhattan after the 9/11 attacks. De Niro has been nominated for eight Academy Awards, winning Best Supporting Actor for "The Godfather: Part II" and Best Actor for "Raging Bull." Despite his serious roles, he has a playful side, famously saying "Are you talkin' to me?" in "Taxi Driver," a line he improvised during filming.
Coco Gauff: Coco Gauff, the American tennis prodigy, made headlines at the age of 15 when she became the youngest player to qualify for Wimbledon in the Open Era, defeating her idol, Venus Williams, in the first round. She has since become one of the youngest players ever to break into the top 50 of the WTA rankings. Off the court, Gauff is known for her activism, using her platform to advocate for social justice and racial equality. In 2020, she joined LeBron James' More Than A Vote initiative to combat voter suppression and encourage young people to participate in the electoral process.
Vanessa Hudgens: Vanessa Hudgens, known for her role as Gabriella Montez in the "High School Musical" series, is also a talented singer. She released her debut album, "V," in 2006, which went on to achieve gold status in the United States. Hudgens is an advocate for sustainable fashion and has been involved in campaigns to promote eco-friendly clothing choices. In her free time, she enjoys painting and has showcased her artwork on social media, revealing another creative side to her talents.
26th Screen Actors Guild Awards: At the 26th Screen Actors Guild Awards held in 2020, the cast of "Parasite" made history by becoming the first foreign-language film to win the Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture. Bong Joon-ho, the director of "Parasite," accepted the award alongside the cast, highlighting the film's universal appeal and breaking barriers in the awards ceremony. The event also marked the first time the awards were held without a host, a decision made to streamline the show and focus more on the performances and winners. Notably, Joaquin Phoenix used his acceptance speech for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Leading Role for "Joker" to advocate for animal rights and environmental sustainability, making a powerful statement beyond the realm of cinema.
Florence Pugh: Florence Pugh made her acting debut at the age of 17 in the British drama "The Falling" (2014), where she starred alongside Maisie Williams. She is also a trained singer and showcased her vocal talents in the film "Lady Macbeth" (2016), for which she received critical acclaim. Pugh is known for her diverse roles, ranging from a medieval bride in "Midsommar" (2019) to a superhero in "Black Widow" (2021). Off-screen, she is an advocate for mental health awareness and has spoken openly about her own struggles, encouraging others to seek help.
Midsommar (film): "Midsommar" is a 2019 horror film directed by Ari Aster, known for its unsettling and vivid portrayal of a Swedish pagan festival. The film was shot in Hungary, not Sweden, to capture the desired remote and isolated atmosphere. Its unique aspect ratio of 2.00:1 was chosen to enhance the immersive and claustrophobic feel of the movie. Despite its gruesome content, "Midsommar" features a predominantly bright color palette, which contrasts sharply with its dark themes, creating a visually striking experience for viewers.
Super Bowl I: Super Bowl I, originally known as the "NFL-AFL World Championship Game," was played on January 15, 1967, at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum. The game featured the Green Bay Packers, led by coach Vince Lombardi, against the Kansas City Chiefs, coached by Hank Stram. The broadcast was split between two networks, NBC and CBS, marking the first time a single sports event was aired on two different channels simultaneously. Despite the historic nature of the game, only 39 million viewers tuned in, a stark contrast to the hundreds of millions who watch the Super Bowl today.
Hugh Laurie: Hugh Laurie, best known for his role as Dr. Gregory House, is a multi-talented artist. He is not only an actor but also a musician, having released multiple albums as a blues musician. Laurie is also a skilled rower; he represented Cambridge University in two Oxford-Cambridge boat races. Interestingly, he almost became a professional rower before choosing a career in acting and music.
State funeral: State funerals are grand public ceremonies held to honor the life of a deceased head of state or other prominent figure. These events often involve elaborate military processions, with soldiers in full regalia marching in unison. One notable feature is the 21-gun salute, which is a traditional military honor performed by artillery units, signifying respect and mourning. Interestingly, the number 21 is derived from the old English tradition of firing three volleys at a funeral, representing the three stages of life: youth, manhood, and age.
Countdown (2019 film): "Countdown" (2019) is a horror film that revolves around an app that predicts the exact moment a person will die. The movie cleverly uses real-world technology and social media platforms to create its chilling premise. One of the film's most intriguing aspects is its exploration of how technology can be manipulated to instill fear and control over users. Despite its terrifying concept, "Countdown" features a scene where a character attempts to cheat death by using a popular dating app to find a new partner, adding a quirky twist to the otherwise grim narrative.
Winston Churchill: Winston Churchill was an avid painter who took up the hobby in his mid-40s to cope with the stress of World War I. He painted over 500 canvases, many of which were landscapes, and once said, "Happy are the painters, for they shall not be lonely." Churchill's paintings were so well-regarded that one was even displayed at the Royal Academy of Arts. His artistic endeavors remained a private pleasure, unknown to the public until after his death.
Prince William, Duke of Cambridge: Prince William, Duke of Cambridge, is an avid soccer fan and has been known to play in charity matches. He is a qualified helicopter pilot, having trained with the Royal Air Force Search and Rescue Force. William is also a patron of over 20 organizations, including the English Rugby Union. Interestingly, he once worked as a volunteer at a homeless shelter in London before his royal duties took precedence.
Ozzy Osbourne: Ozzy Osbourne once bit the head off a live bat during a concert, thinking it was a toy; it turned out to be a real bat, and he had to receive rabies treatment. Despite his notorious image, Ozzy is a devoted animal lover and has owned numerous pets throughout his life, including dogs, cats, and even a baboon named Jordan. He holds the Guinness World Record for the "Most No. 1 Albums by a Metal Act" with his band Black Sabbath. Ozzy's reality TV show, "The Osbournes," which aired from 2002 to 2005, was the first of its kind to reach such high ratings, earning him and his family widespread fame beyond his music career.
Barack Obama: Barack Obama is an avid basketball fan and player; he installed a basketball court at the White House during his presidency. He is known for his preference for a specific type of sandwich, the "hoagie," which he enjoyed during his campaign trail in Pennsylvania. Obama wrote two best-selling books before becoming president: "Dreams from My Father" and "The Audacity of Hope." He was the first African American president of the Harvard Law Review before his political career.
Roger Federer: Roger Federer holds the record for the most weeks spent as the ATP world number one, having spent a total of 310 weeks at the top, including a remarkable 237 consecutive weeks. He has won 20 Grand Slam singles titles, the most by any male player in history. Off the court, Federer is known for his philanthropy; he and his wife Mirka established the Roger Federer Foundation, which has donated over 50 million Swiss francs to help disadvantaged children in Africa and Switzerland. Despite his Swiss nationality, Federer is fluent in four languages: Swiss German, German, French, and English.
Christine Keeler: Christine Keeler, a British model and showgirl, became infamous in the early 1960s due to her involvement in the Profumo Affair, a major political scandal. Keeler's relationships with John Profumo, the British Secretary of State for War, and Yevgeny Ivanov, a Soviet naval attaché, intertwined Cold War tensions with British politics. The scandal led to Profumo's resignation and significantly damaged the reputation of Prime Minister Harold Macmillan's government. Beyond the scandal, Keeler's life was marked by numerous trials, personal struggles, and a persistent public interest in her story.
Peter Tordenskjold: Peter Tordenskjold, a renowned Danish-Norwegian naval hero, was born Peter Wessel in 1690. He gained fame for his daring and successful naval raids during the Great Northern War. Tordenskjold was known for his flamboyant style, including wearing a red coat during battles, which made him a recognizable target. Despite his early death at the age of 30 in a duel, his legacy as a skilled and audacious naval commander remains celebrated in both Denmark and Norway.
Sam Mendes: Sam Mendes, the acclaimed British director, made history by becoming the youngest director to win a Tony Award for Best Direction of a Play at the age of 28 for "The Real Thing." He is also known for his work in film, having directed the James Bond film "Skyfall," which became the first Bond movie to gross over $1 billion worldwide. Mendes is a descendant of the 17th-century English philosopher and poet John Donne, adding a touch of literary heritage to his already impressive resume. Off-screen, he is a keen gardener and has been known to incorporate his love for horticulture into his creative process.
Tom Brady: Tom Brady, the legendary NFL quarterback, holds the record for the most Super Bowl wins by a player, with seven championships to his name. He attended the University of Michigan, where he was a backup quarterback for two years before becoming a starter and eventually being drafted by the New England Patriots. Brady's diet is famously strict, including a regimen that once excluded strawberries due to a supposed allergy, though he later clarified it was more about sensitivity. Despite his success, Brady was actually a 199th overall pick in the 2000 NFL Draft, selected in the sixth round, a fact that has become a testament to his remarkable career trajectory.
Lamar Hunt: Lamar Hunt was a pivotal figure in the founding of both the American Football League (AFL) and Major League Soccer (MLS). He was also instrumental in the creation of the Super Bowl, originally suggesting the name "The Big Game" before it was officially dubbed the Super Bowl. Hunt's vision and leadership not only shaped professional football in the United States but also influenced the development of soccer as a major sport in America. His contributions to sports earned him a place in the Pro Football Hall of Fame.
Rob Lowe: Rob Lowe is an avid fan of the Los Angeles Dodgers, often attending games and sharing his enthusiasm on social media. He made his acting debut at the age of 15 in the television series "A New Kind of Family." Lowe co-founded the production company "Coastal Productions" which was housed on the Sony Pictures lot. In 2011, he released his autobiography titled "Stories I Only Tell My Friends," which became a New York Times bestseller.
Leonardo DiCaprio: Leonardo DiCaprio is named after Leonardo da Vinci because his pregnant mother felt a kick while standing in front of a da Vinci painting in Italy. He started his career by appearing in commercials and educational films before making his way to television series. DiCaprio is a committed environmental activist and has donated millions to environmental causes, including the establishment of the Leonardo DiCaprio Foundation. Despite his immense success, he famously turned down a $30 million payday for a single film to focus on more meaningful projects.
River Phoenix: River Phoenix was an accomplished musician in addition to his acting career; he played guitar and sang in a band called Aleka's Attic alongside his sister Rain. The band was known for its eclectic mix of musical styles and socially conscious lyrics. Despite interest from record labels, Aleka's Attic never signed a deal, partly due to Phoenix's busy acting schedule. Phoenix's musical talents were showcased in the film "My Own Private Idaho," where he performed a song during a scene.
Outlook.com: Outlook.com, Microsoft's email service, was originally launched in 1996 as Hotmail, making it one of the oldest webmail services still in use today. It famously used the "@" symbol in its logo, which was a first for any brand at the time. In 2012, Microsoft rebranded Hotmail to Outlook.com, integrating it with other Microsoft services like Skype and OneDrive. The new interface was designed to compete with other popular email services like Gmail, offering a cleaner, ad-free experience and deeper integration with Microsoft Office tools.
Little Women: "Little Women," written by Louisa May Alcott, was initially published in two volumes in 1868 and 1869. The novel was inspired by Alcott's own childhood experiences with her three sisters. Despite Alcott's initial reluctance to write a "girls' book," "Little Women" became a massive success and has never gone out of print. The story has been adapted into numerous films, TV shows, and even a Broadway musical, making it a timeless classic in American literature.
Derek Jeter: Derek Jeter, the legendary shortstop for the New York Yankees, holds the record for the most hits by a player in the team's storied history, surpassing the previous record held by Lou Gehrig. Off the field, Jeter co-founded the Turn 2 Foundation in 1996, which has awarded over $30 million in grants to various youth programs aimed at promoting healthy lifestyles. Known for his calm demeanor, Jeter earned the nickname "Captain Clutch" for his numerous game-winning hits and performances in crucial moments. Despite his numerous accolades, Jeter famously kept his 2000 World Series MVP trophy in his bathroom to remind himself that even MVPs need to brush their teeth.
Just Mercy: "Just Mercy," a book by Bryan Stevenson, details his work as a lawyer fighting against racial injustice and wrongful convictions. The story is based on the real-life case of Walter McMillian, who was wrongly sentenced to death for a murder he didn't commit. Stevenson's efforts led to McMillian's release after six years on death row. The book has been adapted into a critically acclaimed film starring Michael B. Jordan and Jamie Foxx, further spreading awareness about the flaws in the criminal justice system.
The Circle (American TV series): "The Circle" (American TV series) is a reality competition show where contestants live in separate apartments and communicate solely through a social media platform called "The Circle." The unique twist is that players can choose to catfish others by creating a fake persona using a different name and profile picture. The player who most effectively navigates the social landscape and ranks highest in popularity wins a cash prize of $100,000. The show has been praised for its commentary on modern social media behavior and its addictive, binge-worthy format.
United Kingdom: The United Kingdom is home to the world's oldest underground railway system, the London Underground, which began operating in 1863. One of the quirkiest laws in the UK is the "Dunkirk Spirit" law, which allows pubs to extend their opening hours in times of national emergency. The British Library holds a copy of every book published in the UK, making it one of the largest libraries in the world. The UK has produced more Nobel Prize winners than any other country in Europe, with achievements spanning across various fields including science, literature, and peace.
List of Bollywood films of 2019: In 2019, Bollywood saw the release of over 200 films, showcasing its vibrant and diverse film industry. One of the most notable films of the year was "War," starring Hrithik Roshan and Tiger Shroff, which became the highest-grossing film of 2019 in India. Another standout was "Gully Boy," directed by Zoya Akhtar, which not only received critical acclaim but also represented India in the Best International Feature Film category at the Oscars. The year also marked the debut of several new directors, contributing to the industry's continuous evolution and innovation.
Jerry Rice: Jerry Rice, widely regarded as the greatest wide receiver in NFL history, holds the record for the most receptions, receiving yards, and touchdown catches in a career. He was known for his rigorous off-season training regimen, which included running up sand dunes and catching passes thrown from a mechanical machine. Rice's career spanned 20 seasons, 16 of which were with the San Francisco 49ers, where he won three Super Bowl rings. Despite his advanced age, Rice continued to play at a high level, making the Pro Bowl at age 40 while with the Seattle Seahawks.
Citizenship Amendment Act protests: The Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) protests in India, which began in December 2019, saw a unique form of protest where students and activists used the hashtag #StandWithJNU to express solidarity with the Jawaharlal Nehru University students who were attacked. During these protests, a 26-year-old artist named Manjit Thapp created a digital illustration depicting a map of India engulfed in flames, symbolizing the widespread unrest and the nation's pain, which went viral on social media. The protests also led to the creation of a human chain in Kolkata that stretched over 10 kilometers, involving thousands of people from various walks of life, showcasing the broad-based opposition to the CAA. Notably, these protests were marked by a significant presence of women leading the demonstrations, challenging traditional gender roles and asserting their political voice in the public sphere.
Scarlett Johansson: Scarlett Johansson holds the record for being the highest-grossing actress of all time, with her films collectively earning over $14.3 billion worldwide. She made her film debut at the age of nine in the fantasy comedy "North" (1994). Johansson is also a talented singer, having released two albums: "Anywhere I Lay My Head" in 2008 and "Break Up" in 2009, both showcasing her unique musical style. Despite her busy acting career, she has actively supported various charitable causes, including serving as an Oxfam Global Ambassador since 2005.
List of Marvel Cinematic Universe films: The Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU) films are known for their intricate post-credit scenes, which often tease future installments or connect various films. For instance, the mid-credits scene of "Iron Man" (2008) introduces Samuel L. Jackson as Nick Fury, setting up the concept of the Avengers Initiative. Additionally, "Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2" (2017) features a record-breaking five post-credits scenes, each serving a different purpose, from comic relief to setting up future storylines. These scenes have become a signature element of the MCU, encouraging fans to stay through the credits to catch every detail.
Timoth\u00e9e Chalamet: Timothée Chalamet, known for his roles in "Call Me by Your Name" and "Little Women," once worked as a "concession stand boy" at the famous Tribeca Film Festival before he became a star. He is also a distant relative of musician and fellow actor, Ewan McGregor. During his time at Fiorello H. LaGuardia High School of Music & Art and Performing Arts, Chalamet played the role of King Henry VI in the school's production of "The War of the Roses." Off-screen, he is known for his distinctive style, often wearing outfits that spark fashion conversations at red carpet events.
Penn Badgley: Penn Badgley, known for his role as Dan Humphrey in the hit TV series "Gossip Girl," started his career as a voice actor for video games and animated series at a young age. He is also a talented musician, having released an album with his band MOTHXR, where he serves as the lead vocalist. Badgley is an advocate for mental health awareness and has openly discussed his own struggles with anxiety and depression. Interestingly, he shares a birthday with another famous actor, Zac Efron, both born on October 11th.
Queen Victoria: Queen Victoria was an avid letter writer, sending over 6,000 letters during her reign, many of which were to her close friend and confidante, John Brown, a Scottish servant who was rumored to have been her secret lover. She had a peculiar habit of signing her name with a double 'V' (V.R.) to signify her initials, Victoria Regina. Despite her high status, Victoria loved to play with her children's toys, including a miniature train set that she would operate around the gardens of Osborne House on the Isle of Wight. Her reign, known as the Victorian era, saw significant social, economic, and industrial changes in Britain, making it one of the most transformative periods in the country's history.
David Olney: David Olsey was an American singer-songwriter and playwright known for his storytelling style in music. During a 2019 performance at the 30A Songwriters Festival in Florida, Olney halted in the middle of a song, closed his eyes, and passed away on stage, leaving both the audience and fellow performers in shock. His death was later attributed to a heart attack, and his fellow musicians, including Amy Rigby and Scott Miller, paid tribute to him with heartfelt performances and messages. Despite his sudden passing, Olsey's legacy continues through his extensive catalog of songs and the impact he made on the Americana music scene.
2020 Australian Open \u2013 Women's Sing: In the 2020 Australian Open Women's Singles final, Sofia Kenin, an American, defeated Garbiñe Muguruza from Spain to claim her first Grand Slam title at the age of 21. This marked the first time since 2008 that a player outside the Big Three (Serena Williams, Maria Sharapova, and Venus Williams) won the Australian Open Women's Singles title. Kenin's victory was particularly notable as she came from behind, losing the first set but winning the next two to secure the championship. The match was Muguruza's second consecutive Grand Slam final, having won the previous one at the 2019 Wimbledon Championships.
F5 Networks: F5 Networks is known for its BIG-IP devices, which are advanced traffic management platforms that help ensure high availability, performance, and secure delivery of network services. The company's technology is used in some of the busiest websites and applications worldwide, including those of major banks, e-commerce sites, and social media platforms. F5 Networks also pioneered the concept of Application Delivery Controllers (ADCs), which are now a key component in many enterprise and service provider networks. In addition to its hardware offerings, F5 also provides software solutions and services that help organizations manage and secure their applications and data across various environments, including on-premises, cloud, and hybrid setups.
Larry Walker: Larry Walker, a former Major League Baseball outfielder, was known for his exceptional batting skills and powerful arm. He won seven Gold Glove Awards for his outstanding defense in right field. Walker was also a three-time batting champion, showcasing his prowess at the plate. Interestingly, he was born in British Columbia, making him one of the few Canadian-born players to achieve such high acclaim in MLB.
Pope Francis: Pope Francis is known for his humility and simplicity, often choosing to live in a small apartment rather than the luxurious papal apartments. He has a fondness for the tango, a dance he enjoyed in his youth while growing up in Argentina. The Pope is also an avid soccer fan, supporting the San Lorenzo de Almagro football club. Notably, he became the first pope to visit a prison on his first day of his papacy, washing and kissing the feet of inmates, symbolizing his commitment to serving the marginalized.
John Lynch (American football): John Lynch, a former American football safety, is renowned for his hard-hitting style and leadership on the field. After a stellar NFL career, he transitioned into a successful front office role, becoming the General Manager of the San Francisco 49ers. Lynch was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 2021, highlighting his impact on the game. Interestingly, before his football career, Lynch was also a standout baseball player, drafted by the Florida Marlins in the 1993 Major League Baseball draft.
George MacKay (actor): George MacKay, known for his roles in films like "1917" and "Pride," started his acting career at the age of 10 in the TV movie "The Children's Midsummer Night's Dream." Interestingly, he played the role of a fairy, which required him to wear wings and makeup for the first time in his acting journey. MacKay is also an accomplished violinist and has performed live on several occasions, showcasing his musical talents alongside his acting skills. His diverse talents and early start in the industry have made him a promising and versatile actor in the British film scene.
Margot Robbie: Margot Robbie, known for her roles in films like "The Wolf of Wall Street" and "Birds of Prey," originally hails from a small town in Australia. Before her acting career took off, she worked at a local Subway restaurant. Robbie is also a producer and co-founded her own production company, LuckyChap Entertainment, which has produced several successful films including "I, Tonya." Interestingly, she almost didn't audition for "The Wolf of Wall Street" because she was too busy cleaning floors at the time.
Jane Fonda: Jane Fonda, a renowned actress and activist, holds the distinction of winning an Emmy, a Grammy, and two Oscars, making her one of the few performers to achieve the prestigious EGOT status. Beyond her acting career, Fonda is known for her fitness videos, which she began producing in the 1980s and have sold over 17 million copies worldwide. Her activism has been a significant part of her life, with notable involvement in the anti-Vietnam War movement and more recently, climate change activism. Fittingly, in 2014, she was awarded the American Film Institute's Life Achievement Award, recognizing her multifaceted contributions to the arts and social causes.
Battle of Sinhagad: The Battle of Sinhagad, fought in 1670, was a significant event in Maratha history where Tanaji Malusare, a military leader under Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, recaptured the Kondhana fort. Legend has it that Tanaji used a monitor lizard known as a ghorpad to climb the steep cliff of the fort, showcasing his tactical ingenuity. Despite Tanaji's death during the battle, his sacrifice was honored by Shivaji, who reportedly said, "We have lost the son but gained the fort," cementing Tanaji's legacy as a hero. The battle is celebrated in Marathi culture and is often depicted in plays and literature, highlighting its importance and the valor of its participants.
Will Smith: Will Smith initially gained fame as part of a hip-hop duo with his friend Jeff Townes, known as DJ Jazzy Jeff & The Fresh Prince. He turned down a scholarship to attend the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) because he was more interested in pursuing a career in music and entertainment. Smith was the first rapper to win a Grammy Award for Best Rap Performance and later transitioned successfully into acting, starring in numerous blockbuster films. Despite his success, he maintains a close relationship with his childhood friends and often collaborates with DJ Jazzy Jeff in various capacities.
Sarileru Neekevvaru: "Sarileru Neekevvaru" is a 2020 Telugu-language action comedy film starring Mahesh Babu and Rashmika Mandanna. The film's title, which translates to "Even the most experienced soldier can't handle him," is inspired by a dialogue from the 1990 film "Kondaveeti Donga." The movie features a special appearance by Bollywood actor Sanjay Dutt, marking his debut in the Telugu film industry. "Sarileru Neekevvaru" was a massive commercial success, grossing over 260 crore worldwide, making it one of the highest-grossing Telugu films of 2020.
Messiah (American TV series): "Messiah" is an American thriller series that premiered on Netflix in January 2020. The show revolves around a mysterious man named Al-Masih, who claims to be a divine figure and influences global events, causing a massive international crisis of faith. Despite its intriguing premise, the series was canceled by Netflix after just one season, leaving many plotlines unresolved. The show's unique blend of religious themes and political intrigue sparked widespread debate and discussion among viewers and critics alike.
Zion Williamson: Zion Williamson, the NBA star, was the first overall pick in the 2019 NBA Draft by the New Orleans Pelicans. Despite his massive size at 6 feet 7 inches and 284 pounds, he has an astonishing vertical leap of nearly 40 inches, showcasing his incredible athleticism. Off the court, Williamson is known for his love of video games, often streaming his gameplay on Twitch. His rookie shoe deal with Jordan Brand was reportedly worth $75 million over seven years, making it one of the most lucrative deals for an NBA rookie.
Taal Volcano: Taal Volcano, located in the Philippines, is one of the world's smallest active volcanoes, with a crater lake that makes it a unique sight. Despite its small size, Taal has erupted over 30 times since 1572, making it one of the most active and dangerous volcanoes in the country. The volcano's eruptions have varied dramatically, from small phreatomagmatic explosions to massive plinian eruptions that have affected global climate. The area around Taal Volcano is also a popular tourist destination, known for its scenic views and the opportunity to ride horses to the edge of the crater.
Juice Wrld: Juice Wrld, born as Jarad Anthony Higgins, gained massive popularity with his hit song "Lucid Dreams," which samples Sting's "Shape of My Heart." He was known for his emotional and introspective lyrics, often reflecting on themes of love, loss, and mental health. Juice Wrld passed away at the young age of 21, leaving behind a legacy of music that continues to influence artists and resonate with fans. Despite his short career, he managed to release multiple successful albums and amassed a significant following, cementing his place in contemporary music history.
Severe acute respiratory syndrome-relate: Severe acute respiratory syndrome-related coronavirus (SARS-CoV) is known for causing the SARS outbreak in 2002-2003, which led to over 8,000 cases and nearly 800 deaths globally. This coronavirus is believed to have originated from bats, with civets serving as an intermediary host before transmission to humans. SARS-CoV is characterized by its crown-like spikes, which give coronaviruses their name, derived from the Latin word for "crown." Despite the outbreak being contained, SARS-CoV genetic material has been found in horseshoe bats in China as recently as 2017, indicating its continued presence in nature.
Mahatma Gandhi: Mahatma Gandhi once went on a 24-day salt march to protest British salt taxes, a journey that covered over 240 miles and became a pivotal event in the Indian independence movement. He was a prolific writer, publishing works in Gujarati, English, and Hindi, including his influential autobiography, "The Story of My Experiments with Truth." Gandhi was a vegetarian for ethical reasons and even wrote a book titled "The Moral Basis of Vegetarianism." Despite his non-violent principles, Gandhi once said that if he had to choose between violence and cowardice, he would choose violence.
Graham Chapman: Graham Chapman, best known as a member of the Monty Python comedy troupe, was actually a licensed doctor before he pursued a career in comedy. He studied medicine at Emmanuel College, Cambridge, and later at the Barts and The London School of Medicine and Dentistry. Despite his comedic career, he maintained his medical license until his death. Chapman's dual career path is often highlighted as a testament to his diverse interests and talents.
Impeachment in the United States: Impeachment in the United States originates from the British parliamentary procedure but has evolved uniquely in the American context. The process is outlined in the U.S. Constitution, specifically in Article II, Section 4, which states that the President, Vice President, and other civil officers can be removed from office for "Treason, Bribery, or other high Crimes and Misdemeanors." The House of Representatives holds the power to impeach, acting as a grand jury, while the Senate conducts the trial and votes on conviction. Only three U.S. presidents have faced impeachment proceedings: Andrew Johnson in 1868, Bill Clinton in 1998, and Donald Trump in 2019 and 2021, with none being convicted by the Senate.
Demi-Leigh Nel-Peters: Demi-Leigh Nel-Peters, who won the Miss Universe 2017 title, is an advocate for safety and empowerment, particularly through her "Unbreakable" campaign, which educates women on self-defense techniques. She holds a bachelor's degree in business management from North-West University in South Africa, showcasing her academic prowess alongside her beauty pageant achievements. Demi-Leigh became engaged to American singer Tim Tebow in January 2019, with the couple marrying later that year in South Africa. Notably, her half-sister, Franje, who had cerebral palsy and could not speak, inspired Demi-Leigh's advocacy for those with disabilities, adding a deeply personal dimension to her public service.
Anya Chalotra: Anya Chalotra, known for her role as Yennefer of Vengerberg in the Netflix series "The Witcher," originally hails from a small village in the UK. Before her acting career took off, she worked at a café and as a waitress in Mumbai, India, where she gained insights into different cultures. Anya is multilingual, speaking English, Hindi, and some Marathi, which she learned during her time in India. Despite her rising fame, she remains close to her roots, often visiting her family in the countryside.
Hassan Jameel: Hassan Jameel, a prominent Saudi businessman, is known for his role as the deputy president and vice chairman of Abdul Latif Jameel, a global conglomerate involved in various sectors including automotive distribution, financial services, and real estate. He gained additional public attention when he was romantically linked to international pop star Rihanna, making headlines for their high-profile relationship. Jameel is also involved in philanthropic efforts, supporting initiatives that focus on education, health, and community development in the Middle East. Despite his high-profile connections, he maintains a relatively private personal life, focusing on his business and charitable endeavors.
Microsoft Office: Microsoft Office was initially released in 1989 for the Mac and in 1990 for Windows. The suite's iconic paperclip assistant, Clippy, was designed to help users by providing assistance, but it became so disliked that Microsoft retired it in 2001. Office 365, launched in 2011, marked a shift from traditional software licensing to a subscription model, offering cloud-based services and regular updates. The latest version of Microsoft Office includes AI-powered features like Researcher in Word and Ideas in Excel, enhancing productivity through advanced analytics and writing assistance.
The Road to Wellville (film): "The Road to Wellville," a 1994 comedy-drama film directed by Alan Parker, is based on the novel of the same name by T. Coraghessan Boyle. The film, which satirizes the health and wellness industry of the early 20th century, features a star-studded cast including Anthony Hopkins, Matthew Broderick, Bridget Fonda, and John Cusack. Hopkins' portrayal of Dr. John Harvey Kellogg, the inventor of cornflakes and advocate of bizarre health practices, is particularly memorable. The film was not a commercial success but has since gained a cult following for its quirky portrayal of the Battle Creek Sanitarium and its eccentric founder.
The Lighthouse (2019 film): "The Lighthouse" (2019) is a psychological horror film directed by Robert Eggers, known for its stark black-and-white cinematography and claustrophobic atmosphere. The film features Willem Dafoe and Robert Pattinson as two lighthouse keepers who descend into madness on a remote island. Its use of a 1.19:1 aspect ratio, almost square, is unusual for modern films, enhancing the sense of confinement and disorientation. The film's dialogue is heavily peppered with archaic nautical terms and phrases, adding to its eerie and authentic maritime feel.
Marriage Story (2019 film): "Marriage Story" (2019) features a scene where Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson perform a dramatic argument in a single take, which lasts over five minutes. Director Noah Baumbach wrote the script with specific actors in mind, envisioning Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson for the lead roles. The film was nominated for six Academy Awards, including Best Picture, Best Actor for Adam Driver, and Best Actress for Scarlett Johansson. Baumbach's own divorce inspired the story, and he incorporated personal experiences into the narrative.
Joe Montana: Joe Montana, often referred to as "Joe Cool," led the San Francisco 49ers to four Super Bowl victories, earning three Super Bowl MVP awards along the way. He famously completed a last-minute game-winning drive in Super Bowl XXIII against the Cincinnati Bengals, a feat that solidified his legend. Montana was also a part-time baseball player, drafted by the Montreal Expos in 1974, but he chose to pursue football instead. Despite his football success, Montana has a fear of flying, which occasionally affected his travel schedule during his NFL career.
Junior Seau: Junior Seau, a legendary NFL linebacker, was known for his distinctive pre-game ritual: he would slap himself repeatedly on the face and head to psyche himself up for the game. He played for 20 seasons, primarily with the San Diego Chargers, and was a 12-time Pro Bowl selection. Seau was posthumously inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 2015, following his tragic death in 2012. His #55 jersey is one of the most recognizable in NFL history, and he remains a beloved figure in the hearts of football fans.
The Gentlemen (2019 film): "The Gentlemen" (2019) is a British crime film directed by Guy Ritchie, known for his distinctive fast-paced, witty storytelling style. The film features an ensemble cast including Matthew McConaughey, Charlie Hunnam, and Hugh Grant, who delivers a standout performance as a sleazy private investigator. Ritchie's film cleverly intertwines multiple storylines and perspectives, reminiscent of his earlier works like "Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels" and "Snatch." Notably, "The Gentlemen" marks a return to Ritchie's signature genre after several years focusing on blockbuster franchises like "Sherlock Holmes" and "King Arthur: Legend of the Sword."
Charles Manson: Charles Manson believed in a race war he called "Helter Skelter," which he thought would be triggered by his followers' murders. Despite his notoriety, Manson was once a contestant on "The Dating Game," where he was chosen as the winner by the bachelorette in 1968, unaware of his criminal activities. Manson's music career included an attempt to record with Dennis Wilson of the Beach Boys, who eventually paid Manson to leave his house after experiencing strange behavior from him and his followers. Manson's influence extended to the music world, with bands like Guns N' Roses and Marilyn Manson referencing him in their work.
Laura Dern: Laura Dern, known for her versatile acting career, made her film debut at the age of 11 in the movie "Ladies and Gentlemen, The Fabulous Stains" (1982). Interestingly, she is the daughter of actors Bruce Dern and Diane Ladd, making her part of a Hollywood dynasty. Dern won her first Academy Award for her role in "Marriage Story" (2019), but she had previously been nominated for her performances in "Rambling Rose" (1991) and "Wild" (2014). Her friendship with director David Lynch spans decades, having worked together on multiple projects, including "Blue Velvet" and "Twin Peaks: The Return."
Uncut Gems: "Uncut Gems," directed by the Safdie brothers, features Adam Sandler in a dramatic role that significantly deviates from his typical comedic performances. The film's intense narrative is punctuated by a real-life NBA star, Kevin Garnett, playing a fictionalized version of himself. The movie's soundtrack includes a rare recording of "Sail On, Sailor" by The Beach Boys, which was originally released in 1973. The jewelry store setting in "Uncut Gems" was meticulously designed to resemble a real store in New York City's Diamond District, adding authenticity to the film's gritty atmosphere.
Alan Dershowitz: Alan Dershowitz, a prominent American lawyer and legal scholar, once taught a course at Harvard Law School titled "The Law and Literature of the O.J. Simpson Case," which analyzed the legal strategies and public impact of the famous trial. He has authored over 1000 articles in magazines and newspapers, including the New York Times and the Wall Street Journal. Dershowitz is an avid collector of political buttons and memorabilia, with a collection that spans over a century of American political history. Known for his outspokenness, he has been involved in numerous high-profile cases and controversies, often making headlines with his legal opinions and public statements.
2020 Under-19 Cricket World Cup: The 2020 Under-19 Cricket World Cup, held in South Africa, saw Bangladesh claim their first-ever title by defeating India in the final. The tournament was notable for its high-scoring matches, with a total of 16 centuries scored across the event, breaking previous records. Pakistan's Haider Ali became the youngest player to score a half-century in a U-19 World Cup final at just 15 years old. The event also marked the debut of Afghanistan's Qais Ahmad, who became the first leg-spinner to take a five-wicket haul in the U-19 World Cup.
Adolf Hitler: Adolf Hitler was an avid vegetarian for most of his adult life, and he even banned smoking within his headquarters during World War II. He had a keen interest in architecture and often sketched building designs, which influenced the monumental style of Nazi buildings. Hitler's dog, Blondi, was a German Shepherd who played a significant role in his personal life; he used her to test the effectiveness of a cyanide capsule shortly before his suicide. Despite his strict regime, Hitler was known to have a soft spot for children and established the Winter Relief program to help feed and clothe needy families during the harsh German winters.
Dan Bilzerian: Dan Bilzerian is known for his extravagant lifestyle, which he often showcases on social media. He claims to have earned his wealth through poker, though his actual net worth and sources of income remain a topic of speculation. Bilzerian once ran for President of the United States in 2016 as a joke, garnering some attention despite his lack of political experience. Despite his controversial persona, he has over 32 million Instagram followers, making him one of the most followed individuals on the platform.
Katie Sowers: Katie Sowers made history as the first openly gay and first female coach in the NFL when she joined the coaching staff of the San Francisco 49ers in 2017. She also played a pivotal role in the 49ers' run to the Super Bowl LIV in 2020, marking a significant milestone for women in professional football. Prior to her NFL career, Sowers was a standout player in the Women's Football Alliance, showcasing her athletic prowess both on and off the field. Her advocacy for inclusivity and equality in sports has inspired many, making her a prominent figure in the push for diversity in professional sports.
List of epidemics: The Great Plague of London in 1665-1666, one of the most devastating epidemics in history, famously inspired the young diarist Samuel Pepys to bury his Parmesan cheese and wine in his backyard to protect them from the disease, a quirky act that has become a part of the plague's lore. Despite the city's devastation, the outbreak ended abruptly in 1666, coinciding with the Great Fire of London, which destroyed many of the rat-infested areas and halted the spread of the plague. The bubonic plague also reached the American colonies in the 17th century, with the epidemic of 1693 in Boston causing approximately one-third of the population to perish, marking a significant yet often overlooked chapter in American history. Lastly, the 1918 influenza pandemic, known as the Spanish Flu, was so severe that it is estimated to have killed more people in just twenty weeks than AIDS has killed in forty years, and more in a year than the Black Death of the Middle Ages killed in a century.
Spanish flu: The Spanish flu, which killed an estimated 50 million people worldwide between 1918 and 1920, was so named not because it originated in Spain, but because Spain was neutral during World War I and thus freely reported on the outbreak, unlike war-involved countries. The virus was unusual in that it disproportionately affected young adults, a demographic typically less vulnerable to viral infections. During its peak, the flu was so severe that it reduced the average life expectancy in the United States by about 12 years. Despite its name, the exact origin of the Spanish flu remains uncertain, with potential sources including France, China, and the United States.
Archie Mountbatten-Windsor: Archie Mountbatten-Windsor, the first child of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, was born on May 6, 2019, in Windsor, England. He is seventh in line to the British throne, but his parents decided to forgo a royal title for him, allowing him to grow up with a more private and ordinary life. Archie made his first public appearance on May 8, 2019, when his parents introduced him to the world at Windsor Castle. Interestingly, his birth marked the first time in over 100 years that a senior British royal opted not to pose for photos immediately after a birth, reflecting his parents' desire for privacy.
Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex: Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex, is the youngest son of Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip. He has a background in theater and television, having worked for a time at Andrew Lloyd Webber's Really Useful Theatre Company and later co-founded a television production company called Ardent Productions. Despite being a member of the royal family, Prince Edward holds the record for the lowest number of patronages among his siblings. He is known for his低调的生活方式，经常参与各种慈善活动和皇室职责。
Pope Benedict XVI: Pope Benedict XVI, born Joseph Aloisius Ratzinger, is known for his love of cats; during his time in the Vatican, he often visited and fed the stray cats around the city. He is also a prolific author, having written numerous books on theology and philosophy, including his best-selling work "Jesus of Nazareth." Despite his traditional views, Benedict XVI was the first Pope to resign voluntarily in nearly 600 years, stepping down in 2013 due to health reasons. His resignation set a historic precedent and marked a significant moment in the history of the Catholic Church.
XXXTentacion: XXXTentacion, born as Jahseh Onfroy, had a unique approach to music that often blended various genres, including rap, emo, and rock. Despite his controversial life and early death at 20, he left a significant impact on the music industry and was known for his raw, emotional lyrics. His album "?" featured the hit song "Sad!" which reached number one on the Billboard Hot 100 after his death. XXXTentacion's influence extended beyond music; he was also known for his philanthropy, including efforts to help homeless shelters and support victims of domestic abuse.
Grace and Frankie: "Grace and Frankie" is a popular Netflix series that revolves around two unlikely friends, Grace Hanson and Frankie Bergstein, played by Jane Fonda and Lily Tomlin, respectively. The show, which premiered in 2015, is notable for being one of the first television series to feature a predominantly older cast in leading roles. Throughout its run, the series has tackled various social issues, including ageism, LGBTQ+ rights, and mental health, all while maintaining a comedic tone. Despite its mature themes, "Grace and Frankie" has been praised for its humor and the strong bond between its two main characters, which has resonated with audiences of all ages.
Harvey Weinstein: Harvey Weinstein, once a powerful Hollywood producer, is known for his involvement in the production of numerous successful films, including "Pulp Fiction" and "Shakespeare in Love," which won multiple Academy Awards. His career took a dramatic turn in 2017 when numerous allegations of sexual misconduct and assault were made against him, leading to his arrest and conviction on multiple charges. Weinstein's case has been pivotal in sparking the #MeToo movement, which has encouraged women to speak out against sexual harassment and assault in the workplace. Despite his legal battles and fall from grace, Weinstein's influence on the film industry remains a significant part of Hollywood history.
The Turning (2020 film): "The Turning" (2020) is a psychological horror film based on Henry James' 1898 novella "The Turn of the Screw." The film notably features a non-linear narrative structure, which deviates from the traditional linear storytelling found in most adaptations of the source material. Starring Mackenzie Davis and Finn Wolfhard, the movie was released to mixed reviews, with critics praising the performances but criticizing the confusing plot and ending. Despite its reception, "The Turning" marks an interesting attempt to modernize and reinterpret a classic ghost story for contemporary audiences.
The Good Place: In "The Good Place," the character Janet is an artificial being designed to provide information and assistance to the residents of the afterlife. She has been rebooted numerous times, leading to various iterations with different personalities and knowledge bases. One of the funnier moments in the series involves a reboot where Janet becomes obsessed with the concept of love, much to the confusion and amusement of the other characters. This quirky twist showcases the show's creative approach to humor and its willingness to explore unconventional narrative paths.
Darbar (film): "Darbar" is a 2020 Indian Tamil-language action film starring Rajinikanth as a no-nonsense police officer. The film features an item number by famous Bollywood actress Sunny Leone, which was a surprise inclusion in the otherwise serious action drama. "Darbar" was directed by AR Murugadoss, known for his innovative storytelling and action sequences. Despite mixed reviews, the film was a commercial success, particularly in the overseas market, where it earned over $10 million.
Birds of Prey (2020 film): "Birds of Prey (and the Fantabulous Emancipation of One Harley Quinn)" features Margot Robbie reprising her role as Harley Quinn from "Suicide Squad." The film's title underwent multiple changes before its release, including "Birds of Prey: Harley Quinn" and "Harley Quinn: Birds of Prey." It is the first R-rated movie in the DC Extended Universe. The film's soundtrack includes a song by Megan Thee Stallion titled "Diamonds" which she co-wrote with Normani, who also appears in the film.
Zodiac: The Zodiac is a system used to divide the celestial sphere into 12 equal parts, each represented by a constellation. Historically, the position of the Sun in these constellations at the time of a person's birth was believed to influence their personality and future. However, due to the precession of the Earth's axis, the Sun's actual position at the time of birth no longer aligns with the traditional Zodiac constellations as it did 2,000 years ago. This has led to the introduction of additional, "new" astrological signs, such as Ophiuchus, which was not previously considered a part of the Zodiac.
Derrick Henry: Derrick Henry, the powerhouse running back for the Tennessee Titans, holds the record for the most rushing yards in a single game, with 248 yards against the Jacksonville Jaguars in 2018. Known for his incredible speed and strength, Henry once ran a 4.54-second 40-yard dash at the NFL Combine, despite weighing over 247 pounds. Off the field, Henry is deeply involved in charitable work, including founding the Derrick Henry Family Foundation to support education and youth programs in his hometown of Yulee, Florida. His nickname, "King Henry," not only reflects his on-field dominance but also his regal presence and leadership both on and off the field.
Liverpool F.C. was founded in 1892 following a dispute between the board of Everton and the owner of Anfield, John Houlding, which led to Everton relocating and Houlding establishing Liverpool. The club's anthem, "You'll Never Walk Alone," originally a song from the musical "Carousel," has been sung by the Liverpool fans since the 1960s, symbolizing the strong bond between the team and its supporters. Liverpool holds the record for the most European Cups won by an English club, with six titles, the first coming in 1977 and the most recent in 2019. The club's home kit has traditionally featured red shirts, which were chosen by the legendary manager Bill Shankly, who believed that red represented the power and aggression necessary for success.
Dan Levy (Canadian actor): Dan Levy, known for co-creating and starring in the critically acclaimed series "Schitt's Creek," is also a talented writer and producer. He won an Emmy for Outstanding Writing for a Comedy Series, making him one of the few people to win an Emmy for acting, writing, and producing in the same year. Levy is a vocal advocate for LGBTQ+ rights and has used his platform to promote inclusivity and acceptance. Before his success with "Schitt's Creek," he hosted and co-produced the MTV Canada show "The After Show," where he interviewed celebrities and discussed popular TV shows.
Super Bowl IV: Super Bowl IV, played on January 11, 1970, was the first Super Bowl to feature the Kansas City Chiefs, led by head coach Hank Stram, who famously wore a microphone during the game, providing colorful commentary for NFL Films. The Chiefs, representing the American Football League (AFL), defeated the NFL's Minnesota Vikings 23-7, marking the first and only Super Bowl victory for the AFL before the two leagues merged. Hank Stram's innovative "Red Dog" defensive blitz was a key factor in the Chiefs' victory, as it consistently pressured Vikings quarterback Joe Kapp. This game also marked the end of the AFL-NFL rivalry, as the leagues officially merged the following season, creating a unified NFL with two conferences, the AFC and the NFC.
Bernie Sanders: Bernie Sanders, born in Brooklyn, New York, once worked as a carpenter and filmmaker before his political career. He is known for his love of mittens, famously wearing a pair made from recycled wool during his 2020 presidential campaign. Sanders holds the record for the longest-serving independent in U.S. congressional history, having served in the House of Representatives from 1991 to 2007 and in the Senate since 2007. Despite his political stature, he remains a humble fan of the Boston Red Sox and the English soccer team, Tottenham Hotspur.
Australia: Australia is home to the world's longest fence, the Dingo Fence, which stretches over 5,600 kilometers to keep dingoes away from fertile land and protect livestock. The Great Barrier Reef, visible from space, is the largest living structure on Earth, made up of thousands of coral reefs, islands, and species. Uluru, also known as Ayers Rock, is a massive sandstone monolith sacred to indigenous Australians, and it changes color dramatically at sunrise and sunset. The country is the only one to occupy an entire continent and its surrounding islands.
Caroline Wozniacki: Caroline Wozniacki, a former world No. 1 in women's tennis, is known for her defensive playing style, often frustrating opponents with her ability to run down balls and counter-attack. Off the court, Wozniacki is an avid runner and completed the New York City Marathon in 2014, finishing in an impressive time of 3 hours and 26 minutes. She is also famously known for her relationship with former NBA player David Lee, whom she married in 2019. In January 2020, Wozniacki announced her retirement from professional tennis, ending a career that included 30 WTA singles titles and a Grand Slam victory at the 2018 Australian Open.
LeBron James: LeBron James is known for his philanthropic efforts; he opened the I PROMISE School in his hometown of Akron, Ohio, which provides education and support to at-risk children. Off the court, LeBron has a passion for acting and has appeared in movies like "Trainwreck" and the animated film "Space Jam: A New Legacy." He is also an avid fan of the New York Yankees and has been spotted multiple times at their games, wearing their cap and jersey. Despite his superstar status, LeBron maintains a close relationship with his childhood friends, who have been part of his life since grade school, forming a tight-knit group known as the "Fab Five."
John Millman: John Millman, an Australian tennis player, once defeated Roger Federer at the 2018 U.S. Open in a thrilling fourth-round match that lasted over four hours. This victory, dubbed "Milldermania," was particularly notable as Millman was ranked 55th at the time, making it a significant upset in tennis history. Off the court, Millman is known for his quirky habit of wearing his wristbands inside out, a detail that has caught the attention of many tennis fans. Despite his professional success, Millman holds a Bachelor of Business degree from Bond University, showcasing his academic prowess alongside his athletic achievements.
Joe Rogan: Joe Rogan, known for his popular podcast "The Joe Rogan Experience," started his career as a comedian and later became a commentator for the UFC. He holds a black belt in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu and often discusses martial arts on his show. Rogan is also an avid hunter and has shared his hunting experiences and philosophies on his podcast. Despite his diverse interests, he has faced controversy for his views and the guests he invites on his show.
Doris Miller: Doris Miller, a heroic African American sailor during World War II, gained fame for his actions on the USS West Virginia during the attack on Pearl Harbor. Despite having no prior training in gunnery, Miller took control of an unattended anti-aircraft machine gun and shot down several Japanese planes. His bravery earned him the Navy Cross, making him the first African American to receive this prestigious award during the war. Miller's actions and the recognition he received helped pave the way for greater racial integration in the U.S. military.
Dracula (2020 TV series): In the 2020 TV series "Dracula," the character of Dracula is portrayed by Claes Bang, a Danish actor known for his distinctive looks and acting prowess. The series is co-created by Mark Gatiss and Steven Moffat, who are also known for their work on the popular series "Sherlock." Unlike traditional portrayals, this version of Dracula is depicted with a more modern and sophisticated demeanor, blending classic horror elements with a contemporary twist. The series also features a unique narrative structure, with each episode unfolding in a single day, mirroring the classic novel's epistolary format.
Canada: Canada boasts the longest coastline of any country in the world, stretching over 202,080 kilometers. This vast shoreline is home to diverse ecosystems, including the world-renowned Great Lakes and the rugged shores of the Arctic. The country is also known for its multiculturalism, with over 200 distinct ethnic groups and nearly 20% of its population speaking a non-official language at home. Additionally, Canada is the world's second-largest country by land area, yet it has one of the lowest population densities, with only about 4 inhabitants per square kilometer.
Serena Williams: Serena Williams holds the record for the most Grand Slam singles titles in the Open Era, with 23 major championships to her name. She once played a match in the middle of the night in Thailand, which began at 2:00 AM due to scheduling conflicts and ended with her victory. Serena is also an accomplished fashion designer, having launched her own clothing line called "S by Serena." Off the court, she has a passion for reading and has been known to carry a book with her at all times, even during tournaments.
Chernobyl disaster: The Chernobyl disaster, which occurred on April 26, 1986, is the most severe nuclear accident in history. One of the most iconic images from the disaster is the "Chernobyl Heart" statue, which depicts a heart-shaped tumor, symbolizing the health issues, particularly thyroid cancers, that affected many children in the region. Despite the tragic nature of the event, the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone has become an unexpected wildlife sanctuary, with populations of wolves, deer, and other animals thriving in the absence of human interference. The disaster also led to significant changes in nuclear safety regulations worldwide, influencing the design and operation of nuclear power plants globally.
George V: George V was the first British monarch to broadcast a Christmas message on the radio in 1932, setting a tradition that continues to this day with Queen Elizabeth II. He was also a keen stamp collector and played a significant role in the design of the British Royal Mail's pictorial issues, which featured his profile. Despite being a king, George V had a penchant for plain food and was known to enjoy a simple meal of fish and bread and butter. His personal habits were so well-known that during the Great Depression, his frugality was often cited as an example for the British public to follow.
Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019: The Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019, in India, sparked widespread protests and debates across the country. It is the first law in India to grant citizenship based on religion, excluding Muslims. The act led to the longest internet shutdown in a democracy, in the state of Jammu and Kashmir, as a measure to curb protests. Despite the controversies, the act was upheld by the Indian Supreme Court in a landmark judgment in 2020.
Death of Caylee Anthony: The case of Caylee Anthony's death gained national attention in the United States, largely due to the extensive media coverage it received. Her mother, Casey Anthony, was ultimately acquitted of murder charges in 2011, a verdict that sparked widespread public outrage and debate. The trial featured a high-profile defense team that included Jose Baez, who famously claimed that Caylee had accidentally drowned in the family pool. Despite the acquittal, Casey Anthony was found guilty of providing false information to law enforcement officers.
List of highest-grossing films: The highest-grossing film of all time, adjusted for inflation, is "Gone with the Wind," which was released in 1939. "Avengers: Endgame" holds the record for the highest-grossing film not adjusted for inflation, surpassing "Avatar" in 2019. The top 5 highest-grossing films are all part of either the Marvel Cinematic Universe or the Star Wars franchise. Notably, "Titanic," despite being released in 1997, still ranks among the top ten highest-grossing films when adjusted for inflation.
Jim Lehrer: Jim Lehrer, a renowned American journalist, was known for his distinctive style of moderating presidential debates, emphasizing neutrality and allowing candidates to speak at length without interruption. He co-founded the PBS NewsHour, previously known as The MacNeil/Lehrer NewsHour, which set a standard for in-depth analysis in television news. Lehrer was also an accomplished author, having written over 20 novels, often drawing on his experiences in journalism and politics for his narratives. Despite his serious journalistic career, Lehrer had a quirky side; he once participated in a charity race dressed as a giant ear of corn.
The Two Popes: "The Two Popes," a 2019 film directed by Fernando Meirelles, is based on the play "The Pope" by Anthony McCarten.
