Curb Your Enthusiasm: "Curb Your Enthusiasm" features a unique production style where scripts are loosely outlined, and the actors improvise most of their dialogue. Larry David, the creator and star, often uses real-life annoyances as inspiration for the show's storylines. The series has no laugh track, which is unusual for a comedy, to give it a more natural and immersive feel. Despite its improvisational nature, "Curb Your Enthusiasm" has been nominated for numerous Emmy Awards and has won several, including Outstanding Comedy Series.
2012 Delhi gang rape: The 2012 Delhi gang rape case, which sparked international outrage and massive protests in India, involved a 23-year-old female medical student, referred to as Nirbhaya, meaning "fearless" in Hindi. The brutality of the attack, which included the use of an iron rod, led to her death 13 days later in a Singapore hospital. The case significantly influenced India's laws and led to the death penalty being handed out to four of the convicted attackers. The public outcry following the incident also led to the creation of stricter laws against sexual offenses in India, known as "Nirbhaya Laws."
XFL (2020): The 2020 XFL season, a reboot of the professional football league founded by WWE's Vince McMahon, featured unique rules such as a kickoff alternative called the "opening drive kickoff" where teams started on their 30-yard line and could only move forward. Each team had a "patron" instead of a mascot, a nod to the league's focus on fan interaction and entertainment. The league's abbreviated season was abruptly halted after five games due to the COVID-19 pandemic, marking a sudden end to the ambitious revival attempt. Despite the early closure, the XFL's viewership peaked with an average of 1.9 million viewers per game, showcasing a promising start in the sports entertainment landscape.
Netflix: Netflix started as a DVD rental service by mail before it transitioned to streaming. The company's name is a blend of "net" and "flicks" – a nod to its origins in the internet and film industries. Netflix's first original content series was "Lilyhammer," which premiered in 2012. As of 2021, Netflix has over 200 million subscribers worldwide, making it one of the largest streaming platforms globally.
Michael Jordan: Michael Jordan's nickname "Air Jordan" was coined during his college years after a Sports Illustrated photographer caught him mid-air with a perfect pose, highlighting his gravity-defying jumps. He once appeared as an animated version of himself in the 1996 film "Space Jam," where he helped the Looney Tunes team win a basketball game against alien invaders. Despite his legendary status in basketball, Jordan was initially cut from his high school varsity team, only to return and become one of the greatest players of all time. Off the court, he has a keen interest in golf and has played with several U.S. Presidents, including Barack Obama and Bill Clinton.
John F. Kennedy: John F. Kennedy was the first president to have a telephone installed in the White House swimming pool, allowing him to multitask even while in the water. He was an avid reader and owned one of the largest private libraries in the United States at the time of his presidency, with over 14,000 books. Kennedy's PT-109 boat was rammed and sunk by a Japanese destroyer during World War II, and he famously saved his crew by towing them to safety with a life-threatening back injury. Despite his relatively short presidency, Kennedy established the Peace Corps, a program that continues to this day, promoting world peace and friendship through volunteer service in developing countries.
Lionel Messi: Lionel Messi holds the record for the most FIFA Ballon d'Or awards, having won it a remarkable seven times. He scored his 700th career goal with a penalty kick for Barcelona against Atlético Madrid in June 2020. Messi has a unique trait where his left foot is registered as a trademark in Argentina. Off the field, he is known for his humility and has a close-knit relationship with his family, particularly his mother Celia, who has been a significant influence in his life.
David Dobrik: David Dobrik is a Slovak-born American YouTuber known for his vlog-style videos and comedic content. He co-founded the popular YouTube group "The Vlog Squad," which features a rotating cast of fellow creators. Dobrik briefly held a real estate license and once sold a house to fellow YouTuber Jeff Wittek as a prank. In 2017, he won the Teen Choice Award for "Choice Viner," despite having moved away from Vine to YouTube.
Jos\u00e9 Eduardo dos Santos: José Eduardo dos Santos served as the President of Angola for an unprecedented 38 years, from 1979 until 2017, making him one of the longest-serving leaders in African history. Despite his long tenure, he never officially stood for election until 1992, due to the country's civil war that began shortly after independence. Dos Santos was known for his strategic use of oil wealth to rebuild Angola after the war, though critics argue it also fueled corruption and inequality. After stepping down from the presidency, he briefly returned to politics in 2020 as a member of the National Assembly, but passed away in 2022.
Kray twins: The Kray Twins, Ronnie and Reggie, were notorious British gangsters in the East End of London during the 1950s and 1960s. They were not only feared criminals but also had a surprising celebrity status, with some high-profile friends, including Frank Sinatra and Judy Garland. Their criminal empire included protection rackets, armed robberies, and even murder, yet they maintained a charismatic appeal that led to a cult following. In 1969, they were both sentenced to life imprisonment, with Ronnie being incarcerated in a high-security psychiatric hospital and Reggie in a standard prison, where they remained until their deaths, separated but forever linked in infamy.
Morbius (film): Morbius, a film based on the Marvel Comics character, stars Jared Leto as Dr. Michael Morbius, a scientist who accidentally transforms himself into a vampire-like creature while trying to cure his rare blood disease. The movie was initially met with mixed reviews, with critics praising Leto's performance but criticizing the film's plot and pacing. Morbius was released in theaters on April 1, 2022, and despite its mixed reception, it sparked a viral meme trend on social media, with fans humorously embracing its perceived campiness. The film's release was also notable for its multiple delays due to the COVID-19 pandemic, pushing back its initial July 2020 release date several times.
Matt LaFleur: Matt LaFleur, the head coach of the Green Bay Packers, has a unique coaching lineage; he is one of the few coaches who have worked under both Kyle Shanahan and Sean McVay, two of the NFL's most innovative offensive minds. Before his coaching career, LaFleur played quarterback at Saginaw Valley State University, where he set several school records. His coaching style emphasizes adaptability, often tailoring game plans to suit his players' strengths, which has been a key factor in the Packers' offensive success. Interestingly, LaFleur is one of only three head coaches in NFL history to win 13 games in each of his first two seasons, alongside George Seifert and Pete Carroll.
List of richest people in the world: The list of the world's richest people often features a rotating cast of billionaires, with fortunes fluctuating based on global markets and personal business decisions. Notably, Elon Musk, known for his ventures in electric cars and space exploration, briefly surpassed Jeff Bezos to become the world's richest person in January 2021. The wealth of these individuals is so vast that the combined net worth of the top five richest people could theoretically end world hunger, according to some calculations. Interestingly, the majority of the world's richest people derive their wealth from technology, retail, and investments, reflecting the modern global economy's key sectors.
Richard Jewell (film): "Richard Jewell," directed by Clint Eastwood, is a biographical drama that explores the real-life story of Richard Jewell, a security guard who was wrongly suspected of planting a bomb at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics. The film stars Paul Walter Hauser as Jewell, alongside Sam Rockwell, Kathy Bates, and Olivia Wilde. Bates received an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actress for her role as Jewell's mother. The movie received mixed reviews, with some praising its storytelling and performances, while others criticized its portrayal of the media and the FBI.
The Last Full Measure (2019 film): "The Last Full Measure" (2019) is a war drama that tells the true story of William H. Pitsenbarger, a U.S. Air Force medic who saved over sixty men during the Vietnam War. The film features an ensemble cast including Sebastian Stan, Christopher Plummer, and Samuel L. Jackson, showcasing a range of veteran actors alongside younger talents. Despite its release in 2019, the film took 20 years to complete due to various production challenges and delays. The movie received praise for its powerful storytelling and the performances of its cast, particularly highlighting the emotional depth and historical significance of Pitsenbarger's heroism.
Jennifer Lopez: Jennifer Lopez, often known as J.Lo, started her career as a Fly Girl dancer on the sketch comedy television show "In Living Color" before transitioning to acting and music. She holds the record for the highest first-week sales of any debut album by a female artist in the history of the Billboard Top Latin Albums chart with her album "Como Ama una Mujer." Lopez became the first woman to have a number one album and a number one film at the same time when her album "J.Lo" and the movie "The Wedding Planner" topped the charts in 2001. She is also an accomplished businesswoman, owning a successful clothing and accessories line, a production company, and a fragrance empire.
Ryan O'Callaghan: Ryan O'Callaghan is a former NFL offensive tackle who played for the New England Patriots and the Kansas City Chiefs. After retiring from football, he came out as gay, revealing that his primary motivation for joining the NFL was to avoid coming out and potentially facing backlash. O'Callaghan has since become an advocate for LGBTQ+ issues within sports, using his own experiences to help others in similar situations. He has also written a memoir titled "My Life on the Line," where he shares his journey and the challenges he faced both on and off the football field.
Isaac Asimov: Isaac Asimov, a prolific science fiction author, wrote or edited over 500 books during his lifetime. He is best known for his Foundation series, which predicted a future galactic empire. Asimov was also a biochemistry professor and authored numerous non-fiction works on science, earning him the nickname "The Great Explainer." Interestingly, he once participated in a marathon where he wore a sandwich board advertising his book, finishing the race in just over six hours.
Peaky Blinders (TV series): "Peaky Blinders," a British TV series set in post-World War I Birmingham, takes its name from a real-life street gang known for sewing razor blades into the peaks of their caps. The show's creator, Steven Knight, was inspired by his own family history, as his grandfather allegedly had connections to the real Peaky Blinders. Despite its gritty setting and violent themes, the series features a rich soundtrack dominated by contemporary bands covering classic tracks, including a notable use of the Arctic Monkeys' "R U Mine?" in the opening credits. The character of Tommy Shelby, played by Cillian Murphy, was initially written as a supporting role, but Murphy's performance was so compelling that the character was elevated to the lead.
Vladimir Putin: Vladimir Putin, the President of Russia, is known for his love of animals and has been filmed on several occasions interacting with wildlife, including a Siberian tiger and a polar bear. He is also a skilled judo practitioner and has co-authored a book on the sport titled "Judo: History, Theory, Practice." Despite his tough image, Putin has a soft spot for dogs and has been seen petting and playing with various canine companions during his public appearances. His hobbies include fishing, hunting, and horseback riding, often showcasing these activities in public to highlight his connection with nature and the Russian outdoors.
Russia: Russia is the largest country in the world by land area, spanning over 11 time zones and covering about 17.1 million square kilometers. The Moscow Metro is renowned for its ornate and artistic stations, which are often referred to as "underground palaces" for their beautiful architecture and sculptures. Russia is home to Lake Baikal, the world's deepest and oldest lake, containing about 20% of the world's unfrozen freshwater. The country's history includes the tradition of nesting dolls, known as Matryoshka dolls, which feature a series of smaller dolls nested within a larger one.
Godzilla: King of the Monsters (2019 fil: In "Godzilla: King of the Monsters" (2019), the film features an impressive roster of over 17 monsters, known as Titans, each inspired by real-world mythology and folklore. One of the key scenes in the movie was shot in the ancient city of Oahu, Hawaii, adding a dramatic backdrop to the monster battles. The film's soundtrack, composed by Bear McCreary, includes a unique rendition of the classic "Godzilla" theme, blending traditional orchestral music with modern cinematic elements. Notably, the movie's climactic battle sequence was designed to be viewed in IMAX format, enhancing the visual and auditory experience for audiences.
Millie Bobby Brown: Millie Bobby Brown, known for her role as Eleven in the Netflix series "Stranger Things," started her acting career at the age of eight. She is also a UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador, making her one of the youngest ambassadors in the organization's history. Off-screen, Millie has a passion for music and can play the piano and ukulele. Interestingly, she auditioned for "Game of Thrones" but didn't get the part, which eventually led her to "Stranger Things."
Clint Eastwood: Clint Eastwood, known for his tough-guy roles in Westerns and action films, started his career as a lifeguard at a swimming pool in Oakland, California. He once appeared as an extra in a 1958 episode of "Wagon Train," a role that led to his breakthrough in "Rawhide." Eastwood is also an accomplished jazz composer; he released an album titled "Cowboy Favorites" in 1959, featuring traditional Western tunes. Despite his rugged image, Eastwood served as the mayor of Carmel-by-the-Sea, California, from 1986 to 1988, a small town known for its artistic community.
Taylor Swift: Taylor Swift wrote her first song at the age of 12, a tune about a falling star. She is known for meticulously planning her album releases to coincide with her personal life experiences, often reflecting on past relationships and growth. Swift holds the record for the most wins in the history of the Billboard Music Awards, with a total of 29 wins. She has also ventured into acting, making her feature film debut in the 2014 drama "The Giver."
Sylvester Stallone: Sylvester Stallone once turned down a $330,000 offer for the script of "Rocky," insisting on starring in the film himself. He was so broke at the time that he sold his dog for $25 and later bought it back for $15,000 after the movie's success. Stallone is a devoted painter and has held exhibitions of his artwork, which have been sold for thousands of dollars. Despite his tough-guy roles, Stallone is a certified yoga instructor and practices regularly to maintain his fitness.
John Roberts: Chief Justice John Roberts, known for his meticulous approach to the law, once accidentally referred to a case as "the Slapper" instead of "the Snapper" during a Supreme Court session, causing a moment of uncharacteristic laughter among the usually reserved justices and audience. Despite his serious demeanor, Roberts has a reputation for occasionally injecting humor into his opinions, surprising those who expect a more traditional legal writing style. In 2010, he participated in a skit with Stephen Colbert, where he "administered" a mock Supreme Court oath to a "Colbert" doll, demonstrating a lighter side rarely seen in public. Roberts is an avid fan of opera and has attended performances at the Metropolitan Opera in New York, showing a passion for the arts that contrasts with his professional image as the head of the U.S. Supreme Court.
Singapore: Singapore is known for its strict laws and cleanliness; for instance, it's illegal to chew gum in the country. The city-state boasts the world's first nighttime Formula 1 Grand Prix, which takes place on the streets of Marina Bay. Singapore's Changi Airport, consistently ranked among the best in the world, features a butterfly garden and a rooftop swimming pool. The country is home to the Gardens by the Bay, which includes the Supertree Grove, a collection of tree-like structures that light up in a dazzling display at night.
Selena Gomez: Selena Gomez started her acting career at the age of seven, appearing on the children's television show "Barney & Friends." She gained immense popularity as Alex Russo in the Disney Channel series "Wizards of Waverly Place," which aired from 2007 to 2012. Beyond her entertainment career, Gomez is a passionate advocate for mental health, launching the Rare Impact Fund to support mental health services. Interestingly, she has a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, making her one of the youngest recipients of this honor.
The Masked Singer (British TV series): The Masked Singer UK is a singing competition where celebrities perform in elaborate costumes and masks to conceal their identities. The show's format was adapted from a South Korean series and first aired in the UK in 2020. One of the most surprising unmaskings was when comic actor Jason Manford was revealed as the Hedgehog. The show's unique blend of mystery and musical talent has made it a hit, with viewers eagerly guessing the identities of the masked singers each week.
Love Aaj Kal (2020 film): "Love Aaj Kal" (2020) is a romantic drama film directed by Imtiaz Ali, who also helmed the 2009 original with the same title. The movie stars Kartik Aaryan and Sara Ali Khan in the lead roles, exploring the contrast between modern and traditional love stories. A unique aspect of the film is its narrative structure, which intertwines two parallel love stories set in different time periods—one in contemporary Mumbai and the other in a small town during the 1990s. The film's soundtrack, composed by multiple artists including Pritam, became popular, with songs like "Haan Main Galat" and "Shayad" gaining significant attention.
Floyd Mayweather Jr. is known for his extravagant lifestyle, including owning a fleet of luxury cars, but he also has a philanthropic side; he has donated millions to various charities and educational programs. Despite his flashy persona, Mayweather is a meticulous technician in the ring, having employed a defensive style that has earned him the nickname "Money" for his ability to accumulate wealth through boxing. Outside of boxing, Mayweather has dabbled in various business ventures, including owning a Las Vegas nightclub and promoting his own brand of boxing equipment.
Aleksei Oleinik: Aleksei Oleinik, a prominent Russian mixed martial artist, is known for his unorthodox fighting style that often includes the use of Ezekiel choke, a rare submission hold he popularized in the UFC. Outside the octagon, Oleinik is a devoted family man, with his wife and children frequently attending his fights, showcasing a blend of fierce competitiveness and tender family support. Despite his intimidating presence in the ring, Oleinik holds a degree in physical education and is a certified fitness trainer, revealing a surprising academic background. His career in MMA spans over two decades, making him one of the few fighters to have competed in the inaugural UFC event in 1993 and still be active in the organization today.
Pablo Escobar: Pablo Escobar, the notorious Colombian drug lord, once built a luxurious prison for himself to avoid incarceration, complete with a nightclub, spa, and soccer field. He famously burned $2 million in cash to keep his daughter warm during a trip to the mountains, considering it a better use of money than buying a heater. Escobar's obsession with soccer led him to sponsor the Colombian national team and even attempt to buy a stake in Real Madrid. Despite his immense wealth, Escobar aimed to die as a hero by donating large sums to the poor, earning him the nickname "Robin Hood of the Andes."
Rick and Morty (season 4): In Season 4 of Rick and Morty, episode 6 titled "Never Ricking Morty" is a unique meta-episode that takes the form of a narrative train journey where Rick and Morty encounter various characters from their own show and other stories. This episode cleverly subverts traditional storytelling by blending the show's usual humor with a deep dive into the mechanics of storytelling itself. The episode also features a surprise cameo from a famous actor, adding an extra layer of fun and unexpectedness to the usual Rick and Morty antics.
Jason Momoa: Jason Momoa is a talented actor known for his roles in "Game of Thrones" and "Aquaman," but did you know he has a unique hobby? He enjoys making his own furniture from reclaimed wood and metal. This passion for craftsmanship extends beyond acting, showcasing his versatile skills and creativity. Interestingly, he even built a custom bar for his wife, Lisa Bonet, using a 1965 Ford F-100 truck as the base.
Kamaru Usman: Kamaru Usman, known as "The Nigerian Nightmare," holds the record for the most consecutive wins in the UFC's welterweight division, with 15 straight victories. He became the UFC Welterweight Champion by defeating Tyron Woodley at UFC 235 in 2019. Usman is a former freestyle wrestler who represented Nigeria at the 2010 Commonwealth Games. Despite his intimidating nickname, Usman is known for his humble demeanor outside the octagon, often engaging with fans and giving back to his community in Nigeria and the United States.
John Cleese: John Cleese, best known for his work in Monty Python, once co-owned a hotel in Somerset, England, called the Fawlty Towers Hotel, which inspired the name of the famous sitcom "Fawlty Towers." He is also an avid fan of wildlife and has narrated several documentaries, including those for the BBC's "Life" series. Cleese holds the record for the longest comedy sketch in history, clocking in at 45 minutes, which was performed during a Monty Python live show in Aspen, Colorado. Despite his comedic fame, Cleese has a degree in Law from the University of Cambridge.
Global warming: Global warming has caused a significant increase in the melting of Arctic ice, leading to the emergence of new islands in the region. In 2016, a previously submerged island appeared near the coast of Greenland, surprising locals and scientists alike. This phenomenon not only alters the geographical landscape but also affects local ecosystems and indigenous communities. The newly formed islands can also change shipping routes and access to resources, impacting global trade and exploration activities.
Coronaviridae: Coronaviridae, the family of viruses that includes the infamous SARS-CoV-2, is named after the Latin word for 'crown' due to the distinctive crown-like spikes on their surface. These spikes are actually proteins that help the virus attach to and infect host cells. Interestingly, the first coronavirus was identified in the 1930s in chickens, causing bronchitis, but it wasn't until the 1960s that the viruses were discovered in humans, causing both respiratory and intestinal diseases. The complexity of the coronavirus genome, which is one of the largest among RNA viruses, allows it to evolve rapidly, making it a significant challenge in terms of vaccine development and disease control.
Mimi Keene: Mimi Keene, a British actress, is best known for her role as Cindy Williams in the popular British TV series "EastEnders." She transitioned to the fantasy genre with her portrayal of Bianca in the Netflix series "The House of the Dragon," a prequel to "Game of Thrones." Keene is also an accomplished ballet dancer, having trained at the prestigious Italia Conti Academy of Theatre Arts. Despite her young age, she has already made a significant impact in both television and film, showcasing her versatility and talent in the entertainment industry.
Elvis Presley: Elvis Presley was known for his love of peanut butter, banana, and bacon sandwiches, a quirky combination he often enjoyed late at night. During his time in the army, Elvis befriended a chimpanzee named Scatter, who would often accompany him on his motorcycle rides. He once bought a Rolls-Royce Phantom V, which he customized with velvet seats and shag carpeting, and gifted it to his mother. Elvis's iconic hairstyle was not originally planned; his hair was naturally wavy, and after a failed attempt to straighten it, his hairdresser decided to style it into the now-famous pompadour.
Gabriel Martinelli: Gabriel Martinelli, the Brazilian forward for Arsenal, made his debut for the club in September 2019 and scored in that match, becoming the youngest player to score on his Premier League debut for Arsenal since Nicolas Anelka in 1999. Despite his young age, Martinelli has shown remarkable maturity and skill, earning him a spot in the Brazil national team's senior squad. Off the pitch, he is known for his humble demeanor and dedication to his craft, often seen practicing diligently even after team sessions. His rapid rise in the football world has made him a fan favorite and a promising star for both club and country.
Mufidah Abdul Rahman: Mufidah Abdul Rahman is a Singaporean human rights activist known for her work in advocating for the rights of migrant workers. She co-founded the Humanitarian Organization for Migration Economics (HOME), an organization that provides support and legal assistance to migrant workers in Singapore. Mufidah was awarded the International Women of Courage Award by the U.S. State Department in 2016, recognizing her exceptional courage and leadership in advocating for human rights. Despite facing numerous challenges, her relentless efforts have significantly improved the lives of countless migrant workers in Singapore.
Abraham Lincoln: Abraham Lincoln was an avid fan of the theater and often attended performances in his spare time. Despite his love for the arts, he experienced a tragic irony when he was assassinated by actor John Wilkes Booth at Ford's Theatre in Washington, D.C. Lincoln was also known for his sense of humor; he once said, "If I were two-faced, would I be wearing this one?" referring to his plain, unassuming appearance. Interestingly, Lincoln was the first U.S. president to be photographed at his inauguration.
Super Bowl XLVI: Super Bowl XLVI, held in 2012, featured a dramatic rematch between the New York Giants and the New England Patriots, the same teams that faced off in Super Bowl XLII. During the halftime show, Madonna performed a medley of her hits, including "Vogue," and was joined by LMFAO, Nicki Minaj, and M.I.A., the latter of whom caused controversy by flipping the middle finger during her brief appearance. The game itself was notable for a crucial fourth-quarter touchdown pass from Eli Manning to Mario Manningham, which set up the game-winning drive. The Giants ultimately won the game 21-17, marking their second Super Bowl victory over the Patriots in five years.
2017 Las Vegas shooting: The 2017 Las Vegas shooting, which occurred on October 1, 2017, was the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history at the time, with 58 people killed and 851 injured. The shooter, Stephen Paddock, fired from the 32nd floor of the Mandalay Bay hotel into a crowd of 22,000 people attending the Route 91 Harvest music festival. In the aftermath, a GoFundMe campaign for the victims raised over $11 million, making it one of the highest-funded campaigns on the platform. Despite extensive investigations, the motive behind the attack remains largely unknown.
Zombieland: Double Tap: "Zombieland: Double Tap" features a cameo by actor Luke Wilson, who plays a doppelganger of Jesse Eisenberg's character, Columbus. The film includes a scene where the characters travel to the White House, which is overrun by zombies, a nod to the original "Zombieland." Director Ruben Fleischer incorporated practical effects alongside CGI to enhance the zombie action sequences, giving the film a more tactile feel. The movie's title is a reference to the technique of "double tap," which is shooting a zombie twice to ensure it's truly dead, a rule prominently featured in the first film.
Post Malone: Post Malone, whose real name is Austin Richard Post, has a unique way of choosing his stage name; he used an online rap name generator to come up with it. Interestingly, he initially planned to go by "Malone" but added the "Post" to honor his last name. Post Malone is known for his eclectic musical style, blending elements of hip-hop, pop, rock, and country. Despite his tattoos, which include a large face on his chest and a sword on his arm, Post Malone is afraid of needles and only got his first tattoo at the age of 20, after overcoming his fear.
Tom Cruise: Tom Cruise, born Thomas Cruise Mapother IV, holds a unique distinction in Hollywood for performing many of his own stunts, which has earned him a reputation as one of the most daring actors in the industry. One of his most iconic stunts was hanging off the side of a flying Boeing 747 airplane for the filming of "Mission: Impossible – Rogue Nation." Cruise is also an avid follower of the Church of Scientology, which he joined in the late 1980s and has since become one of its most prominent members. Despite his high-profile career and personal life, Cruise remains dedicated to maintaining a close relationship with his children, often incorporating them into his travel schedules and public appearances.
2016 United States presidential election: The 2016 United States presidential election featured the first major-party female nominee, Hillary Clinton, who ran against businessman and reality TV star Donald Trump. During the campaign, Trump faced significant criticism for his remarks about women, which were widely publicized and controversial. Despite polls suggesting a Clinton victory, Trump won the election, marking one of the biggest upsets in American political history. The election also saw a record number of voters casting their ballots for third-party candidates, reflecting widespread dissatisfaction with the major party options.
Henry VIII of England: Henry VIII of England was an avid sportsman, particularly fond of jousting, which he participated in regularly despite several serious accidents, including one that left him unconscious for two hours. His passion for food was equally notable; he consumed a diet so rich that it was estimated to be equivalent to eating 8,000 Big Macs in a year. Henry VIII was also a composer and musician, credited with writing "Pastime with Good Company," a piece of music that became popular during his reign and is still performed today. Despite his many talents, Henry VIII is perhaps most famously remembered for his six marriages and his dramatic break with the Roman Catholic Church to form the Church of England.
Rooney Mara: Rooney Mara is not only an accomplished actress but also a dedicated philanthropist. She co-founded the charity Faces of Kibera, which aims to provide food, education, and medical care to orphans in Kenya's Kibera slum. Mara adopted a vegan lifestyle and became a spokesperson for PETA, advocating for animal rights and ethical fashion. In 2011, she underwent a dramatic transformation for her role as Lisbeth Salander in "The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo," shaving her head and getting multiple piercings, which showcased her commitment to her craft.
Manson Family: The Manson Family, led by Charles Manson, was a quasi-commune in California in the late 1960s. Charles Manson believed in a race war prophesied in the Beatles' White Album, which he referred to as "Helter Skelter." The group's infamous murder spree included the killing of actress Sharon Tate, who was eight months pregnant at the time. Manson and his followers were known for their use of LSD and other psychedelics, which Manson believed would help them achieve a higher state of consciousness.
Tate\u2013LaBianca murders: The Tate-LaBianca murders, orchestrated by Charles Manson and his "Family," were initially misconstrued as the work of a drug cult due to the cryptic messages left at the crime scenes, such as "Pig" written in blood on a door. One of the victims, Rosemary LaBianca, was found with a fork and a knife placed on her stomach in a manner suggesting she was killed while eating; the knife had "WAR" written on it in her blood. The trial of the Manson Family became one of the most publicized in American history, with the courtroom antics of Manson and his followers adding to the media frenzy. Despite the gruesome nature of the crimes, the phrase "Helter Skelter," which Manson believed would incite a race war, was actually a song title from The Beatles' "White Album," misinterpreted by Manson.
Ashleigh Barty: Ashleigh Barty, the Australian tennis star, retired from professional tennis at the age of 25, making a surprising announcement in March 2022. Prior to her tennis career, Barty played cricket and was a wicket-keeper for the Brisbane Heat in the Women's Big Bash League. She made a triumphant return to tennis after a brief hiatus, winning the 2019 French Open and climbing to the top of the WTA rankings. Barty is also known for her love of golf and has expressed interest in potentially playing professionally in the future.
Meghan Markle: Meghan Markle, before becoming a member of the British royal family, had a successful acting career, most notably starring as Rachel Zane in the popular legal drama series "Suits." She is also an avid foodie and once ran a lifestyle blog called The Tig, where she shared her favorite recipes, travel destinations, and beauty tips. Meghan is passionate about social issues and has been involved in various humanitarian efforts, including serving as a Global Ambassador for World Vision, where she traveled to Rwanda for a clean water campaign. Interestingly, she has a double major in theater and international relations from Northwestern University, showcasing her diverse academic and professional interests.
Super Bowl XXXI: Super Bowl XXXI, held in 1997, was the first Super Bowl to feature a halftime show with a major pop star, as Michael Jackson headlined the event, drawing one of the largest audiences in American television history at the time. The game saw the Green Bay Packers defeat the New England Patriots 35-21, with Packers' cornerback Tyrone Hughes becoming the first player in Super Bowl history to return both a kickoff and a punt for a touchdown. The game's MVP, Packers' quarterback Brett Favre, threw for 246 yards and two touchdowns, while also running for a touchdown himself. The Vince Lombardi Trophy was presented by Vince Lombardi's widow, Marie Lombardi, marking a poignant moment in the event's history.
2020 United States presidential election: The 2020 United States presidential election saw a record-breaking number of mail-in ballots due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with over 65 million cast by mail, surpassing the total number of mail-in votes from the 2016 election. Joe Biden became the first presidential candidate in history to surpass 80 million votes, receiving over 81 million votes in total. The election also featured the highest voter turnout in a presidential election since 1900, with approximately 66.8% of eligible voters casting their ballots. Additionally, for the first time in 120 years, both major-party presidential candidates were over the age of 70, with Joe Biden being 78 and Donald Trump being 74.
Johnny Depp: Johnny Depp has a passion for music and plays multiple instruments, including guitar and drums. He has collaborated with various artists and even formed his own band, The Kids, in the 1980s. Depp has made guest appearances on albums by famous musicians like Alice Cooper and Oasis. His musical talents have occasionally been showcased in his film roles, such as his character Jack Sparrow's impromptu guitar session in "Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest."
Walter McMillian: Walter McMillian was a Black man who was wrongfully convicted of murder in Alabama in 1987 and sentenced to death. His case gained national attention when it was highlighted in the book and later film "Just Mercy," written by Bryan Stevenson. Despite overwhelming evidence of his innocence, McMillian spent six years on death row before his conviction was overturned in 1993. His story serves as a powerful example of the flaws in the criminal justice system, particularly regarding race and the death penalty.
Black Death: The Black Death, a devastating pandemic that swept through Europe in the 14th century, was caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, primarily spread by fleas on rodents like rats. During its peak from 1347 to 1351, it killed an estimated 200 million people, nearly one-third of Europe's population, making it one of the deadliest pandemics in human history. Surprisingly, the plague led to economic shifts and social upheavals, including the decline of feudalism as the labor shortage caused by the deaths led to higher wages and the rise of a money-based economy. The term "Black Death" itself was not used until the 18th century, long after the pandemic had subsided.
Mikhail Mishustin: Mikhail Mishustin, the current Prime Minister of Russia, has a background in music; he played the bass guitar in a rock band during his university years. Prior to his political career, Mishustin worked for the Federal Tax Service of Russia for over two decades, eventually becoming its head. His appointment as Prime Minister in January 2020 came as a surprise to many, as he was not a widely known political figure before that. Mishustin is known for his pragmatic approach and has focused on economic reforms and digitalization during his tenure.
Amazon (company):
Amazon was originally named "Cadabra" after the magic word "abracadabra," but founder Jeff Bezos changed it to Amazon because he liked the idea of being associated with the world's largest river.
The company started in Jeff Bezos' garage in 1994, initially selling books online before expanding into a vast array of products and services.
Amazon's first major expansion beyond books was selling CDs, and Bezos personally packed and shipped many of the early orders.
In 2017, Amazon acquired Whole Foods Market for $13.7 billion, marking a significant step into the physical retail space and allowing Amazon to integrate its services directly into grocery shopping.
Shivaji: Shivaji Bhosale, also known as Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, was a 17th-century Maratha ruler known for his strategic use of guerrilla warfare. He established the Maratha Empire in western India with the creation of the Swarajya concept, which emphasized self-governance and resistance against foreign rule. Shivaji was skilled in both maritime and land warfare, and he built a formidable navy to protect the coastal regions of his kingdom. His coronation as Chhatrapati (Emperor) in 1674 marked the formal establishment of the Maratha sovereignty, which significantly influenced the political landscape of India.
Neil Peart: Neil Peart, the drummer and lyricist for the rock band Rush, was an avid motorcyclist and traveled extensively on his bike. He once rode over 55,000 miles across North America, which inspired the lyrics for the album "Rush." Peart was also a prolific writer, having authored several books on his travels and experiences. His drumming style was highly technical and influential, earning him the nickname "The Professor" among fans and fellow musicians.
Mehcad Brooks: Mehcad Brooks, known for his role as Malcolm Bennet on "Supergirl," is also a former model who started his career by appearing in a series of Eggo Waffles commercials. He made his acting debut in the Oscar-winning film "Glory Road" where he played a basketball player. Brooks is an advocate for body positivity and has spoken openly about embracing his natural physique in an industry that often promotes a specific body type. Off-screen, he enjoys playing basketball and is a fan of the NBA team, the Los Angeles Lakers.
Stephen Hawking: Stephen Hawking was a renowned theoretical physicist who achieved fame despite being diagnosed with a motor neuron disease at the age of 21. Despite the doctors predicting he would only live for a few more years, Hawking lived an astonishing 55 years beyond their prognosis. He authored the best-selling book "A Brief History of Time," which aimed to make complex scientific theories accessible to the general public and became an international phenomenon, selling over 10 million copies. Hawking also made a cameo appearance in the popular television show "The Simpsons," showcasing his sense of humor and ability to connect with a broader audience.
List of highest-grossing Indian films: The highest-grossing Indian film of all time is "Baahubali 2: The Conclusion," which not only shattered box office records in India but also performed exceptionally well internationally, becoming the first Indian film to cross the $200 million mark worldwide. This epic action film, directed by S.S. Rajamouli, is a sequel to the 2015 blockbuster "Baahubali: The Beginning" and is known for its grand visual effects and elaborate sets. Interestingly, "Baahubali 2" was released in four different languages—Telugu, Tamil, Hindi, and Malayalam—simultaneously, making it a pan-Indian cinematic phenomenon. The film's success has been attributed not just to its spectacular action sequences and storytelling but also to its innovative marketing strategies, including a unique promotional event where the first look was unveiled at the Wembley Stadium in London.
Darth Vader: Darth Vader, originally known as Anakin Skywalker, was once a promising Jedi Knight. His transformation into the iconic Sith Lord was largely driven by his desire to save his wife, Padmé Amidala, from death. Vader's signature breathing sound was created by designer Ben Burtt using the sound of a scuba tank regulator. Despite his villainous persona, Darth Vader has a soft spot for his son, Luke Skywalker, ultimately leading to his redemption and death in "Return of the Jedi."
Nick Kyrgios: Nick Kyrgios once hit a 163.7 mph serve during a match at the 2016 Wimbledon Championships, which was the fastest serve recorded in the tournament's history until 2022. He is known for his fiery on-court demeanor, which has both endeared him to fans and drawn criticism from others. Off the court, Kyrgios is an avid basketball fan and has been spotted attending NBA games and interacting with players. Despite his controversial reputation, he has a philanthropic side, having raised funds for the Australian bushfire relief in 2020.
William Shakespeare: William Shakespeare's will, written just days before his death in 1616, is filled with fascinating details, including the bequest of his "second-best bed" to his wife, Anne Hathaway. This unusual gift has sparked centuries of speculation about the couple's relationship. Interestingly, Shakespeare's will makes no mention of any of his famous plays or poems, suggesting he may have viewed them as less significant than his personal possessions. Additionally, the Bard's signature on the will, which appears 20 times, is the only surviving example of his handwriting.
Super Bowl LIII: Super Bowl LIII, held in 2019, was the lowest-scoring Super Bowl in history, with the final score of the New England Patriots defeating the Los Angeles Rams being 13-3. The game featured only one touchdown, which was scored by the Patriots in the fourth quarter. The halftime show was headlined by Maroon 5, alongside guests Travis Scott and Big Boi, but it received mixed reviews from audiences. The game's total viewership was down significantly compared to previous years, sparking discussions about the declining interest in the NFL.
Frogmore Cottage: Frogmore Cottage, located on the grounds of Windsor Estate, was originally built in the early 19th century as part of a row of worker's cottages. The cottage underwent extensive renovations in 2018-2019, transforming it into a luxurious home for Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, who lived there before stepping back from their royal duties. Its name derives from the nearby Frogmore House, a royal retreat known for its beautiful gardens and connections to several members of the British royal family. Despite their departure, Frogmore Cottage remains a significant part of the couple's history, symbolizing their early years as a royal family.
Akanksha Puri: Akanksha Puri, an Indian actress and model, is known for her roles in both Bollywood and the South Indian film industry. She gained significant recognition for her portrayal of Goddess Parvati in the TV series "Vighnaharta Ganesh." Outside of her acting career, Puri is an avid animal lover and has been involved in various charitable activities, particularly those focused on animal welfare. Her social media presence is vibrant, often showcasing her glamorous photoshoots and behind-the-scenes glimpses of her life and work.
Under-19 Cricket World Cup: The Under-19 Cricket World Cup, first held in 1988, is a prestigious tournament that serves as a launchpad for future international stars. Notable players like Virat Kohli, Kane Williamson, and Joe Root have all participated in this event before making their mark in senior cricket. The tournament has seen its format evolve, with the number of teams increasing from 16 in the inaugural event to 16 in the most recent edition. In 2020, Bangladesh made history by winning their first-ever Under-19 Cricket World Cup title, defeating India in the final.
Elizabeth Warren: Elizabeth Warren is an avid birdwatcher and has been known to take breaks during her workdays to observe and identify birds in the area around her office. She once taught a class on bankruptcy law at Harvard Law School while heavily pregnant with her second child. Warren is a fan of the Boston Red Sox and has been spotted at several games, often wearing team memorabilia. She authored or co-authored over a dozen books before launching her political career, focusing primarily on economic issues affecting middle-class families.
Academy Awards: The Academy Awards, also known as the Oscars, were first broadcast on radio in 1930 and then on television in 1953. The iconic Oscar statuette, officially called the "Academy Award of Merit," is made of gold-plated bronze and stands 13.5 inches tall, weighing 8.5 pounds. Despite its name, the statuette was never actually made of gold until 1982 when the current alloy was introduced. The award ceremony holds the distinction of being the oldest entertainment awards show in the world, predating both the Emmy Awards for television and the Grammy Awards for music.
Circles (Mac Miller album): "Circles," the final album by Mac Miller, was completed by producer Jon Brion after Miller's untimely death in 2018. The album debuted at number three on the Billboard 200, marking Miller's sixth consecutive top-five entry on the chart. Its release was accompanied by a posthumous music video for the single "Good News," which has amassed over 100 million views on YouTube. "Circles" received widespread acclaim for its introspective lyrics and cohesive sound, earning Mac Miller a posthumous nomination for Best Rap Album at the 2021 Grammy Awards.
Tyreek Hill: Tyreek Hill, known as the "Cheetah," holds the NFL record for the fastest 100-meter dash time by a player at 10.19 seconds, showcasing his incredible speed. Before his NFL career, Hill was a standout track athlete at Oklahoma State University, where he competed in the 60 meters, 100 meters, and 200 meters. Despite facing significant personal challenges, including a domestic violence case that led to his dismissal from Oklahoma State, Hill has transformed his life and career, becoming one of the league's most dynamic wide receivers. In 2022, Hill signed a massive contract with the Miami Dolphins, worth up to $120 million over four years, making him one of the highest-paid receivers in the NFL.
Dolly Parton: Dolly Parton, known for her iconic blonde wigs, once revealed that she has worn wigs since she was a teenager because they make getting ready easy; she can change her look in minutes. Parton is also a literacy advocate; her Imagination Library program mails free books to children from birth to age five in the United States, United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, and Ireland. Despite her fame and wealth, Parton still lives in the same Nashville area where she grew up, in a house she bought from her mother. She is famously generous, having donated millions to various causes, including over $1 million to the COVID-19 research that led to the development of the Moderna vaccine.
Tennessee Titans: The Tennessee Titans' name is steeped in local history; it was inspired by the "Tennessee Titan," a statue of a Titan god located in Nashville's Centennial Park, which itself is a replica of the ancient Greek statue of Zeus at Olympia. The team's logo features a pair of swords crossed behind a blue star, symbolizing the team's defensive prowess and the star's connection to Nashville's nickname as the "Athens of the South." Originally known as the Houston Oilers, the team moved to Tennessee in 1997 and played temporarily at the Liberty Bowl in Memphis and Vanderbilt Stadium in Nashville before settling into their current home, Nissan Stadium, in 1999. The Titans made a dramatic run to Super Bowl XXXIV, narrowly losing to the St. Louis Rams in the final seconds, famously known as "The Tackle" by linebacker Mike Jones on Titans wide receiver Kevin Dyson at the one-yard line.
Priyanka Chopra: Priyanka Chopra is not only an actress but also a singer; she released her debut single "In My City" in 2012, which featured will.i.am and was a commercial success in India. She is also a philanthropist, having been appointed as a UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador in 2016, focusing on promoting the rights of children and adolescents. Additionally, Chopra is a savvy businesswoman; she launched her own hair care line, Anomaly, in partnership with the retail giant Target in 2021. Her diverse talents extend beyond the screen, as she holds the title of Miss World 2000, making her one of the few beauty queens to achieve significant success in both entertainment and philanthropy.
Pantone 448 C: Pantone 448 C, also known as "Opaque Couché," is famously known as the "world's ugliest color." It was chosen in 2012 by the Australian government to be used on cigarette packaging to deter smoking, as it was found to be the least appealing color to the human eye. The dark brownish-green shade has a hexadecimal code of #4A412A. Despite its unpopularity in aesthetics, Pantone 448 C has played a unique role in public health by discouraging tobacco use through its unappealing appearance.
Matthew McConaughey: Matthew McConaughey was once arrested in 1999 after a neighbor reported loud music and a bongo drum session at his Austin, Texas home. During the arrest, police found him dancing naked and playing the drums. Despite the incident, he managed to turn the experience into a humorous story, often recounting it in interviews and public appearances. This event did not hinder his career; instead, it added to his reputation as a laid-back and unconventional celebrity.
Japan: Japan is home to over 6,000 islands, but only around 430 of them are inhabited. The country's iconic Mount Fuji is not only a sacred site but also an active volcano, last erupting in 1707. Japanese trains are renowned for their punctuality, with some bullet trains known to arrive at their destinations within seconds of their scheduled time. Lastly, the Japanese language uses three different writing systems: kanji (Chinese characters), hiragana, and katakana, which are used in various combinations to convey meaning.
Antony Armstrong-Jones, 1st Earl of Snow: Antony Armstrong-Jones, 1st Earl of Snowdon, was a British photographer and film maker who gained fame not just for his artistic talents but also for his marriage to Princess Margaret, the younger sister of Queen Elizabeth II. Their wedding in 1960 was the first royal event to be broadcast on television, making it a significant moment in media history. Despite his aristocratic title, Snowdon continued to work as a professional photographer, capturing portraits of notable figures including Elizabeth Taylor and Laurence Olivier. His work was recognized with a BAFTA in 1956 for his documentary "Royal Family," which offered an intimate look into the lives of the British monarchy.
Edward VII: Edward VII, who reigned as King of the United Kingdom from 1901 to 1910, was known for his love of food and was often referred to as "Edward the Caresser" due to his numerous romantic liaisons. Despite his reputation, he was instrumental in easing diplomatic tensions in Europe, which earned him the nickname "Peacemaker." Edward VII was the first British monarch to visit Japan, making the journey in 1901, which significantly improved Anglo-Japanese relations. His coronation in 1902 was postponed due to an emergency appendectomy, the first time in British history that a royal surgery was publicly acknowledged.
Tom Hardy: Tom Hardy is known for his versatile acting skills, but before his acting career took off, he was a model for a clothing brand at the age of 21. He has a passion for martial arts and holds a blue belt in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu. Hardy is also an animal lover and has been known to bring his dogs to the set of his movies. Despite his tough-guy roles, he has a soft spot for charitable causes, particularly those involving veterans and children.
Stranger Things: "Stranger Things" was almost called "Montauk" as the original concept was based on conspiracy theories surrounding the real-life Montauk Project in New York. The show's creators, the Duffer Brothers, initially struggled to find a young actor for the role of Eleven, but Millie Bobby Brown's audition left them so impressed that they rewrote parts of the script to better suit her talents. The iconic title sequence was created by a fan of the show who was hired after the Duffer Brothers saw his work on a fan site. The show's soundtrack, featuring retro synthesizer music, was chosen to evoke the atmosphere of the 1980s, a decade beloved by the creators.
Kedar Williams-Stirling: Kedar Williams-Stirling is a British actor known for his role as Miles Sampson in the popular Netflix series "Sex Education." Before his acting career took off, Williams-Stirling trained at the Identity School of Acting in London. He has also appeared in other notable TV shows like "The Dumping Ground" and "Inspector George Gently." Off-screen, Williams-Stirling is an advocate for mental health awareness and often uses his platform to encourage open conversations about mental health issues.
Maleficent: Mistress of Evil: "Maleficent: Mistress of Evil" is a 2019 fantasy film that serves as a sequel to the 2014 film "Maleficent." In this movie, Angelina Jolie reprises her role as the titular character, Maleficent, who discovers more about her mysterious past and her connection to the magical creatures of the Moors. The film introduces a new character, Queen Ingrith, played by Michelle Pfeiffer, who schemes to destroy the fairy-realm and its inhabitants. The movie features stunning visual effects and a blend of live-action and CGI, showcasing a variety of fantastical creatures and landscapes.
Albert Einstein: Albert Einstein once said that if he hadn't been a physicist, he would have been a musician. He played the violin and often used music as a way to relax and stimulate his thinking. Einstein had a special fondness for Mozart's music, which he believed had a perfect balance of beauty and simplicity. On a visit to Oxford in 1931, he even participated in a Mozart string quartet performance, showcasing his musical talents alongside his scientific genius.
Tom Hanks: Tom Hanks is known for his habit of wearing a different watch on each wrist during filming, a tradition he started to keep track of time zones for scenes set in different locations. He once sent a typewriter to a fan who admired his love for the vintage machines, after discovering the fan's address through a heartfelt letter. Hanks co-created the World War II miniseries "Band of Brothers" and insisted on using real veterans as consultants, ensuring historical accuracy. He holds the distinction of being the first actor to appear in back-to-back Best Picture winners, with "Forrest Gump" (1994) and "Philadelphia" (1993).
Vikings (season 6): In Season 6 of "Vikings," the character Ivar the Boneless undergoes a significant transformation, shifting from a ruthless warrior to a more contemplative leader as he navigates the complexities of ruling Kiev. This season introduces a new character, Gunnhild, who becomes a formidable warrior and a key ally to Bjorn Ironside, showcasing her strength and strategic mind. The series also delves deeper into the Norse mythology, with episodes featuring the appearance of the gods and the exploration of their impact on human affairs. Additionally, the season finale sets the stage for a potential spin-off series, focusing on the adventures of Ubbe as he journeys to discover the fabled land of Vinland.
Bruce Lee: Bruce Lee was so fast that his moves were often too quick for the camera to capture at standard film speeds, leading to the need for cameras to shoot at 32 frames per second to properly record his speed. He developed his own martial art called Jeet Kune Do, which means "the way of the intercepting fist," emphasizing flexibility and practicality in combat. Despite his short film career, Lee's influence on martial arts and cinema is profound, with many action films and stars emulating his style. Before his untimely death at age 32, Bruce Lee was planning to star in a film adaptation of "The Silent Flute," a project that would have taken him to India, where he intended to study Eastern philosophies and spirituality.
Ryan Reynolds: Ryan Reynolds holds both American and Canadian citizenship, making him a dual citizen. He once worked as a grocery store clerk before his acting career took off. Reynolds is known for his sense of humor, often engaging in playful banter on social media, particularly with Hugh Jackman. He co-owns the production company Maximum Effort, which has produced several of his films, including "Deadpool."
Bad Boys (franchise): The "Bad Boys" franchise, starring Will Smith and Martin Lawrence, was initially conceived as a one-off film but became a hit, leading to the sequel "Bad Boys II" released eight years later. The third installment, "Bad Boys for Life," was delayed multiple times but eventually released in 2020, marking a 17-year gap since the previous film. Despite the lengthy intervals between films, the franchise has grossed over $840 million worldwide, solidifying its status as a successful action-comedy series. The chemistry between Smith and Lawrence is often credited as a key factor in the franchise's enduring popularity.
2019 in film: In 2019, the film "Avengers: Endgame" became the highest-grossing movie of all time, surpassing "Avatar," before re-releases bumped "Avatar" back to the top in 2021. The movie "Parasite" made history by becoming the first non-English language film to win the Academy Award for Best Picture. Quentin Tarantino's "Once Upon a Time in Hollywood" featured a scene that was a tribute to the Spahn Ranch, where Charles Manson's followers lived, and it was filmed at a different location to avoid disturbing the actual site. The documentary "Apollo 11" was praised for its use of never-before-seen footage from the 1969 moon landing, providing a fresh and immersive look at the historic event.
Super Bowl XLVII: Super Bowl XLVII, held in 2013, featured the infamous "Blackout Bowl" when a power outage at the Mercedes-Benz Superdome in New Orleans caused a 34-minute delay in the game. The Baltimore Ravens were leading 28-6 at the time of the outage, but the San Francisco 49ers managed to narrow the score to 28-23 after play resumed. The Ravens ultimately won the game 34-31, securing their second Super Bowl title. The power outage was later attributed to an abnormality in the Superdome's electrical load system.
Find My iPhone: Find My iPhone is a feature that helps users locate their lost or stolen Apple devices. It utilizes GPS and Wi-Fi signals to pinpoint the device's location on a map. If the device is offline, Find My iPhone can still help by sending a notification once the device comes back online. One unique feature is the ability to play a sound on the lost device, even if it's set to silent mode, which can be particularly helpful in locating it within a house or office.
Chinese zodiac: The Chinese zodiac is a repeating cycle of 12 years, with each year being represented by an animal and its reputed attributes. Interestingly, the order of the animals in the zodiac was determined by a race held by the Jade Emperor, a legendary ruler of the heavens in Chinese mythology. The clever rat managed to secure the first position by riding on the back of the ox and jumping off just before the finish line. This unique method of selection has influenced the cultural and superstitious beliefs associated with each animal sign, affecting everything from personality traits to fortune-telling practices in Chinese society.
Ariana Grande: Ariana Grande started her career on Broadway at the age of 15, playing the role of Charlotte in the musical "13." She later transitioned to television, starring as Cat Valentine in the Nickelodeon series "Victorious" and its spin-off "Sam & Cat." Ariana is known for her impressive vocal range, which spans over four octaves, and she often incorporates the whistle register into her performances. In 2016, she broke the record for the most simultaneous Billboard Hot 100 entries by a female artist, with 14 songs on the chart.
